column2: CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 3 (UPI)--A Delta Airlines 727 jetliner with 89 passengers aboard made an emergency landing at Charleston International Airport last night because the cabin had lost pressure. One person was hospitalized. The aircraft, on the way from Orlando, Fla., to New York City, landed safely, the airline said.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 3-- Each day, sometimes twice or three times a day, small groups of Arabs, wearing gold Rolex watches whose value in the past six months has nearly doubled, slip into a second-floor suite of the Intercontinental Hotel here.
Anyone could see that the Rev. Donald Hanson's forehead was damp with sweat, so Pope John Paul II did the only charitable thing and pulled out a handkerchief to mop the surprised priest's brow.
The field for Saturday's $350,000 added Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont Park may develop into the smallest for this thoroughbred race in more than 30 years.
IN case you hadn't noticed, this year is the Centennial of Light. That little switch you flip so casually is being celebrated officially by the Smithsonian Institution.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 3--Gerald Lewis, Florida State Comptroller and chairman of the Florida for Kennedy Committee, charged today that procedures for the Oct. 13 county caucuses were "stacked" in favor of President Carter and against the movement to draft Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts.

A SKYJACKING thriller by Mary McCarthy? Well, yes: In "Cannibals and Mission aries," Miss McCarthy's sixth novel and 17th book, an Air France B-747 does get diverted at gunpoint from its destination at Teheran and is ...

UNTIL recently, there were petroleum analysts in Wall Street who had never heard of the Bel ridge Oil Company of California. Thanks to a spirited bidding contest, however, little-known Belridge has become a hot property--and a hot stock.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI)--The Pentagon said today that Rear Adm. Thomas Replogle had been named to head the new joint task force headquarters in Key West, Fla., and Defense Secretary Harold Brown will meet with him there on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI)--Republican colleagues today urged Senators Jacob K. Javits of New York and Barry Goldwater of Arizona to seek re-election next year and increase the party's chances of winning control of the Senate for the first time in a generation.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3--Pope John Paul II was welcomed by exuberant crowds here this afternoon and, in a mass attended by hundreds of thousands of people at Logan Circle, emphasized basic human freedoms while warning against "laxity regarding the Christian view on sexuality."
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 3 --"The starting quarterback will be Phil Simms," Ray Perkins intoned today at the luncheon in the Giants' press-box lounge. "I know that comes as a big surprise."

Coward, McCann Geoghegan is making room at the top starting Jan. 1, with everybody getting promoted one notch and nobody scheduled to depart. The publisher is part of the Putnam Publishing Group, which includes G.P. Putnam's Sons.
Tighter regulation of sidewalk cafes in New York City, proposed by the city's Planning Commission, received support yesterday from neighborhood groups and restaurant operators.
DO you speak Dogg? "You don't learn it. You catch it," says a character in Tom Stoppard's "Dogg's Hamlet, Cahoot's Macbeth," which opened last night at 22 Steps Theater.

A German antiquarian dealer in the provincial city of Furth recently purchased for resale two copies of Naziera printings of Adolf Hitler's "Mein Kampf." Brought to trial by the public prosecutor, acting under a law that prohibits the dissemination of literature produced during the Nazi period, the dealer was found guilty, fined, and his two books were confiscated.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 3--At a quick glance, the Pittsburgh Pirates fit their nickname better than any other baseball team. With their mustaches, beards and sometimes straggly hair, they indeed resemble pirates.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3--In a comfortable new subdivision on the outskirts of Los Angeles, living the life many Americans aspire to, dwells the Vietnamese Lee family--father, mother, three children.

Charging that high school students throughout New York City had been "manipulated" by their athletic coaches, School Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola vowed yesterday that the protest would "not work" and that police action would be used to prevent further demonstrations during the school day.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 3--While Chile's Supreme Court was refusing to extradite to the United States this week three army officers accused of planning a political assassination in Washington, Anaconda was signing a contract to in vest up to $1.5 billion in a new copper mine here.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3--On the day the Pope came here to visit, Marie DiNubile arose before dawn, washed her front windows, step and sidewalk before her neighbors went to work, and gave a free loaf of bread to the first woman who entered her small store-- all of which she has done every morning for decades.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Oct. 3 (AP)-- Health officials, warned by a bizarre anonymous letter, said today that hundreds of people might have been exposed to a suspected cancer-causing chemical deliberately dumped in three swimming pools.

BUFFALO, Oct. 3 (AP)--A State Supreme Court justice today rejected a $2.5 billion class-action claim filed on behalf of about 900 residents and former residents of the old Love Canal chemical dump site neighborhood in Niagara Falls.

BAN LAEM, Thailand, Oct. 3 (AP)-- At the entrance to the camp, on the Cambodian side of the border, a young boy stood awaiting the visitors, his spindly limbs and distended belly testifying to malnutrition.

HOUSTON, Oct. 3 (Reuters)-- Tenneco Inc. said today that an exploratory well off New Jersey was being abandoned as a dry hole by its Tenneco Oil exploration unit. The company said it represented the first test of outer continental shelf acreage acquired last February in the second Federal lease sale for the Baltimore Canyon.

In the midst of a grueling schedule that will probably reach a crescendo today when he travels from Philadelphia to Des Moines to Chicago, Pope John Paul II is impressing many observers and colleagues with his powers of recuperation from strain.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP)--President Carter sent to Congress yesterday a package of proposed legislation that is intended to protect rivers in 11 states. He also urged expansion of the nation's National Trails System.

QUEBEC, Oct. 3 (AP)--Mike Bossy scored two goals as the New York Islanders came back from a 2-0 deficit to score a 6-2 triumph over the Quebec Nordiques in a National Hockey League preseason game tonight.

A well-known Aztec emperor was unmentioned last week when President Carter talked with President Lopez Portillo. Having learned one lesson about Mexican sensitivity, the Carter Administration seems about to absorb another--this time about oil.

Ross M. Hett, 47 years old, is expected to be elected president and chief operating officer of the Avco Corporation at its board meeting on Oct. 26, the company announced. He is to succeed George L. Hogeman, 62, who will become vice chairman. James R. Kerr, 62, remains chairman and chief executive officer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP)--The Senate Agriculture Committee approved a $2 billion-a-year rural energy plan today. Supporters of the legislation said the plan could make American food and forest industries independent of foreign energy by the year 2000.
BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 3--The Labor Party's annual conference voted today to deny the party leader any voice in the drafting of manifestoes, or electoral campaign platforms.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 3 (AP)-- The Tennessee Valley Authority today got approval to complete its $140 million Columbia Dam, thus winning its second battle in a week against an endangered species.
BRUSSELS, Oct. 3 (AP)-- Belgium's central bank today raised the discount rate, at which it lends to private banks, by one percentage point to 10 percent. It is the fifth increase since late May.

LACOCK, ENGLAND WITH its medieval abbey and Tudor cottages, framed by rolling green countryside, this village 100 miles west of London is as pretty as a picture. It is also, coincidentally, the home of William Henry Fox Talbot, generally credited as the "father of modern photography."

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 3 (AP)--A native of El Salvador wanted for questioning in connection with a letter that said Pope John Paul II would be shot in New York was questioned in San Salvador and released today, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3--A Defense Department study has concluded that the United States should bolster China's military potential so that Peking could assist the West in a war with the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3--The Senate Select Committee on Ethics said today that it had uncovered half a dozen or so possible violations of Federal laws in its long investigation into Senator Herman E. Talmadge's finances.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3--The United States International Trade Commission ruled today that imports of ammonia from the Soviet Union were harming American producers.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I.--The world is flat in this part of the Long Island plain, and this scientifically discredited impression seems a strange setting for the research into past and future that goes on in the Life Sciences Building at Hofstra University.

The Texas International Company and the NFC Corporation, two Oklahoma City companies in the oil and gas exploration business, announced that they had agreed in principle to a merger valued at about $65 million.

One way or another--from a seat in Yankee Stadium or Shea, a window high above a motorcade route, from a street corner or a church pew--millions of Americans will at least catch a glimpse of Pope John II this week. As many more probably wish that they could, for reasons that are perhaps as varied as the crowds.

MORRILTON, Ark., Oct. 3 (AP)-- Two men were sentenced today to die in the electric chair on June 3, 1980. Judge Charles Eddy of Conway County Circuit Court imposed the sentence on Paul Ruiz and Earl Van Denton after a recommendation by the jury. Yesterday, the same jury found the men guilty of capital murder in the 1977 slayings of Marvin Richie of Magazine and Opal James of Havana.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3--President Carter personally interceded in an effort to persuade Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel to receive the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, the black activist leader, American and Israeli sources said today.

THEY are real estate offices and swimming pool service centers in Austin, Tex; SevenEleven stores in Wyandotte, Mich.; a jewelry store in Philadelphia, and a Baptist church in Springfield, Mo. In Utah, one is an artist's studio, and in Venice, Calif., one is even a home.

Dear young people, I am happy to be with you in Madison Square Garden. Today, this is a garden of life, where young people are alive. Alive with hope and love. Alive with the life of Christ. And it is in the name of Christ that I greet each one of you today.

Roy Harris, one of the more prolific and more renowned of American composers, died on Monday in a hospital in Santa Monica, Calif., after a series of strokes. He was 81 years old. He had been composer in residence at California State University, Los Angeles, for 10 years and had been professor of music emeritus at the University of California at Los Angeles.
The gifts of New Yorkers to Pope John Paul II were as varied as their givers and the circumstances under which they were given.

WASHINGTON FEDERAL officials last week unveiled a fast-acting sprinkler system for the home that they hope will be the key to their goal of cutting in half the loss of life and property in residential fires over the next 20 years.
Gold futures came under increased selling pressure yesterday after the major London bullion dealers slashed their second fixing by $24 an ounce from Tuesday's final price setting.

A city panel yesterday granted a 20year real-estate tax abatement for the renovation and reopening of the Royal Manhattan Hotel on Eighth Avenue between 44th and 45th Streets. It turned down an abatement request by the Sotheby Parke Bernet auction house for an additional location in Manhattan on York Avenue at 72d Street.
Two youths indicted for murder when they were 14 years old for a fire that killed seven persons last year in the South Bronx were permitted yesterday to plead guilty to the lesser charge of burglary.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4(AP)--The Carter Administration told Congress today that there might be another major surge of refugees in Southeast Asia caused by a new Vietnamese offensive in Cambodia as well as by resumed ejections of ethnic Chinese and others from Vietnam.
Algeria, the fifth-largest supplier of oil to the United States, is planning an additional cutback of 5 percent in contract sales of crude to major oil companies on Jan. l, analysts said yesterday.
Ruth Orkin's whole life, from her earliest days, has been images rather than words.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 4(AP)--Striking office workers, whose walkout has stopped production by some major studios and film processors, have reached a tentative agreement on a contract and might return to work next week, a Federal mediator said yesterday.
BAN LAEM, Thailand, Oct. 4--In increasing numbers, skeletal victims of Cambodia's famine are trooping into this Thai border village.

BONN, Oct. 4--United States efforts to explore the possibility of a new international aid package for the dollar have met with only measured West German support, a reception that bankers and money-market analysts consider certain to limit the extent of any such plan.

Some 1,200 major corporations in the United States will have to show the impact of inflation on their sales and earnings in 1979 when they issue their annual stockholder reports for the year, according to a new ruling to be issued today by the Financial Accounting Standards Board.
Food, music and other entertainment can be enjoyed alfresco tomorrow from noon to 6 P.M. at a block party on East 74th Street, between Second and Third Avenues. Sponsored by the 74th Street

The depressed state of the credit markets became more pronounced yesterday and interest rates continued to climb to record levels, pushed higher by discouraging wholesale price figures, a tightening signal from the Federal Reserve and the absence of any forceful program to bolster the dollar.

BASIC BOOKS has sold the paperback rights to Douglas Hofstadter's "Godel, Escher, Bach," to Vintage Books for $200,000. It was more money than Basic Books, a nonfiction publisher whose

HOUSTON, Oct. 4--A Federal appeals court today struck down as illegal the suspended sentences, with probation, that were imposed on three former police officers in Houston who were convicted last year of violating the civil rights of a Mexican-American who drowned after he was beaten and pushed into a downtown bayou.

THE new "Oklahoma!" will open at the Palace Theater on Dec. 13. The original "Oklahoma!" opened on March 31, 1943, closed May 29, 1948, and had 2,205 performances in between. This new "Oklahoma!" is being produced by Zev Bufman and James Nederlander, and in an earlier, less elaborate version it was intended only for Mr. Bufman's theaters in Florida.
FASHIONS in Mozart performance seem to undergo 180-degree changes about every 20 years, possibly because of the push and pull of generational antagonisms as much as scholarly discoveries

Investor-owned utilities continued to reduce appropriations for new plant and equipment in the second quarter of this year, according to a report by the Conference Board that will be released today. These lower appropriations will contribute to lower spending in months to come because capital appropriations are authorizations to spend money in the future.

HOBOKEN, N.J.--The nightmare of officials involved in improving the housing of lower-income people goes like this: newly built units will be poorly managed; maintenance will slide; subsidy needs will grow; localities will denounce new failures by subsidized housing; Congress will become alarmed; programs will be suspended or funds cut back further than they recently have been.
A plunge in gold prices and an increase in the value of the dollar against several major foreign currencies enabled the stock market to score a moderate advance yesterday in active trading.

John C. Traphagen, retired president and chairman of the Bank of New York, died Tuesday in St. Vincent's Hospital in Bridgeport, Conn. He was 90 years old and was a longtime resident of West Nyack, N.Y.

The areas of New York City that Pope John Paul II visited were clean by midday yesterday--some cleaner than they usually are--despite the crowds that had gathered to greet the Pope in the two previous days.

Widespread rumors that the Carter Administration was planning new measures to support the dollar led to a strengthening of the American currency yesterday in foreign-exchange trading, while gold prices plummeted on world bullion markets.

Now that Soviet troops in Cuba no longer provide a pretext for delaying the SALT treaty, its path seems blocked mainly by those who would hold it hostage for a commitment to higher defense spending. WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--A. Daniel O'Neal Jr., chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, said today that he would not seek reappointment when his term expires Dec. 31. Instead, he said, he would leave the Government, after 13 years of service, for "mostly personal reasons."
THE teamwork is terrific. Then why isn't "The All Night Strut!" more fun? It turns out that teamwork isn't what we most want in the theater.

TRIPOLI, Libya--The notions that women are too fragile to compete with men and that a child belongs at its mother's knee and not in a nursery may not sound particularly progressive. But such convictions amount to revolutionary dogma in Libya today when they are voiced by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 4--A state judge ruled today that Mayor Frank Logue had abused his authority in closing the Winchester gun factory here on Monday because he expected violence in connection with a company plan to bring in nonunion workers during a strike.

With their first joint meeting since performances were suspended Sunday set for today at 2 P.M., both sides in the labor dispute at the New York City Opera agree that their differences have been narrowed to $342,000.
A prominent professor at New York University was indicted yesterday on charges that he used his university laboratory for the illicit manufacture of LSD, methaqualone and other drugs for profit.

WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn., Oct 4-- Michael Jepeal, a 25-year-old bowlingalley mechanic, was pleading with an elderly woman at the Bradley Bowl here as the roof buckled and then broke in several places.

IT didn't rain Tuesday evening. Yet an umbrella opened at 54th Street and 10th Avenue. This particular umbrella was the Dance Umbrella, which began a 10week season featuring 20 groups with an "Event" by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9--At the very least, Pope John Paul II has demonstrated something we have forgotten in America and even tend to deny: that a solitary individual with strong convictions and noble aspirations still touches the heart of a vast continental nation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4(UPI)--Madalyn Murray O'Hair, the militant atheist, took her fight against Pope John Paul II to a Federal appeals court today, seeking to stop him from celebrating mass on Washington's public Mall next Sunday.

David Karr, a little-known entrepreneur who was one of the leading American businessman in East-West trade, spent last Fourth of July in Moscow celebrating the opening of an American-style luxury hotel he had developed. A few days later he was found dead in his Paris apartment, at the age of 60.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 4 (Reuters)--Residents of central Yugoslavia fled from their homes early today when a strong earthquake caused some damage but no casualties. The strongest tremors were felt in Sarajevo.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 4 --Aaron U. Jones was on a hunting trip in Idaho, so his wife and co-owner represented him in the winner's circle tonight as Valdez, their 3-year-old colt, beat four rivals in the $106,300 Rutgers at the Meadowlands.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--In a report to be issued tomorrow, the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence states that the United States has impressive ability to monitor many facets of Soviet military development. But, Senate sources said today, it draws no firm conclusion that the new strategic arms treaty can be adequately verified.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--Last Monday was New Year's Day for the fiscal year 1980. By that date the Federal budget was supposed to have been in place and the money to pay the bills was supposed to have been appropriated.

TACOMA, Wash., Oct. 4(AP)--Corky Corcoran, the tenor-saxophone player known for his work with the Harry James orchestra and other groups in the 1940's, died yesterday in St. Joseph's Hospital here. He was 55 years old.

WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 4(UPI)--A Federal judge, whose restraining order had forced Amtrak to keep three money-losing trains running four days past their cancellation deadline, lifted the order today, allowing the railroad to eliminate the trains.

The orderly world of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell Co. is being shaken by an unusual insurgent challenge in the election to name a successor to Walter E. Hanson as chairman of the nation's largest accounting firm.

JOURDONTON, Tex., Oct. 3--At the top of this state's police pyramid are the renowned Texas Rangers. On the next level, but still highly regarded, are the troopers of the Texas Highway Patrol, widely respected in the state for professionalism and even-handedness in enforcing the law.

SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 4(UPI)--A wealthy Salvadorean businessman, investigated and cleared by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of involvement in an alleged plot to kill the Pope, said today that the whole thing was "a bad joke."

STOCKPORT, N.Y.--Adelaide Eckhoff stood at the edge of Stockport Creek the other day and watched the rushing waters tumble down Chittenden Falls on the way to the Hudson River and the sea. "Look at all that water going to waste," she said. Her husband, Paul, added, "Think of all the electric power it could generate."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4(AP)--The Carter Administration proposed three possible ways today to enforce its promised oil-import allocation program, a move that might cut American dependence on the oil cartel, but could raise oil prices.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4(AP)--The White House press office today announced $17.1 million in grants to help 44 cities and counties finance the rehabilitation of urban park and recreation systems.
When Robert Abrams was a junior at Columbia University he feared that he would get the worst mark in his political science class.

Food Fair Inc. received approval yesterday for its preliminary debtrepayment plan in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. The supermarket chain was also granted court approval to proceed with a five-year, $205 million capital-improvements program.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 4-- South Africa's finance minister suggested today that there was a rough historical relationship between oil and gold prices under which either gold should fall sharply or oil rise again.
Estaban DeJesus, the former world lightweight champion, failed to show his former class tonight as he scored a 10-round unanimous decision over Jimmy Blevins of Chicago at the Felt Forum.

IF Malcolm McDowell took a particular pleasure in ordering a $40 Pomerol after consultations with the sommelier at lunch one day recently, it was because not so many years ago he was the wine waiter at his father's restaurant-pub, The Bull and Dog, in Burscong, a village outside Liverpool.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4(AP)-- President Carter accepted the resignation of Commerce Secretary Juanita M. Kreps today "with the greatest reluctance and regret."

CLEVELAND, Oct. 4(Reuters)-- The Alcan Aluminum Corporation, United States subsidiary of Alcan Aluminium Ltd., said today that it had increased the price of 99.5 percent minimum purity ingot to 66 cents a pound effective immediately.

The weekly mah-jongg and poker party at the Towers at Water's Edge in Bayside, Queens, was crashed by five gunmen in ski masks Wednesday night. When the action was over, 37 players had lost $12,000 in cash and $53,000 in jewelry, the police reported yesterday.

An event that may eventually determine whether the New York Mets are sold to John O. Pickett Jr., the New York Islanders' chairman of the board, apparently took place in a fatherdaughter conversation in Maine over the Labor Day weekend.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4--Pope John Paul II came to the heart of the country today, emphatically reaffirming in his crosscountry tour that the Roman Catholic priesthood required a lifelong commitment from men and was not a proper calling for women.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 4 (Reuters)--The censors have lifted their ban on "Burger's Daughter," a novel by Nadine Gordimer that has been widely hailed overseas.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4--The Pittsburgh Pirates came home today only one game short of winning their first National League pennant in eight years, and Manager Chuck Tanner offered a prediction: "Affirmed will beat Spectacular Bid all the way Saturday at Belmont Park."
Silver futures plummeted and gold futures extended a three-day decline yesterday amid persistent talk that the Carter Administration will move to shore up the dollar.
Affirmed and Spectacular Bid will have a little more company in tomorrow's Jockey Club Gold Cup than anyone had expected.

The Rev. Joseph Olinski had faith. He believed firmly--and for weeks had been telling anyone who asked him --that the Pope would show up at his church, St. Stanislaus Bishop and Martyr on East Seventh Street in Manhattan.
OSCEOLA MILLS, Pa., Oct. 4(UPI) --Marilyn J. McCusker, who sued for the right to be a coal miner, has been killed by falling rocks while working in a mine, officials announced yesterday.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 4(AP)--Richard E.F. Leakey, whose fossil finds helped establish the concept that eastern Africa was the cradle of mankind 3.5 million years ago, is ill in London and will receive a kidney transplant from a brother, the Leakey family said today.
"The Long Way to Boston" will be at The Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam through Nov. 18. Performances are at 8:30 P.M. today, at 5 and 9 P.M. tomorrow and at 5 P.M. on Sunday.

OLYMPIA, Wash., Oct. 4(AP)--Gov. Dixy Lee Ray has closed a low-level nuclear waste dump, one of three in the country, until she receives assurances from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that proper inspections of packaging would be made at the site of origin.

Roger Knowlton Fawcett, who was president of Fawcett Publications, the company founded by his father, and an award-winning sportsman, died Wednesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital. He was 69 years old.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 3--Four months after an oil well in the Gulf of Mexico blew out its fittings, a torrent of oil is still pouring into the maritime environment, and attempts by the Mexican authorities and American contractors to cap the well appear to be floundering.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--Secretary of the Army Clifford L. Alexander today tentatively approved the building of the first major oil refinery on the East Coast in 22 years, overriding objections from environmentalists.

Student leaders from high schools throughout the city agreed yesterday to give the School Chancellor a week to find a solution to the job action by coaches that has stopped all competitive sports but football.

LONDON, Oct. 4(UPI)--The Times newspaper group, shut down by a labor dispute since last November, reached agreement today with one of its most militant unions. But other unions must come to terms before The Times and its sister publications reach the streets.
More than 2,000 "farmers"--of both the commercial and backyard variety --have entries in this weekend's Long Island Fair, the largest agricultural fair in New York State.

Gert von Gontard, who devoted the money he inherited as a grandson and heir of Adolphus Busch of the AnheuserBusch brewing company to bringing European theater and opera companies to America, died Saturday in Zurich. He was 73 years old and lived in Zurich and New York.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4(AP)--President Carter approved authority today for 13 United States airlines to fly from American cities to Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

PEKING, Oct. 4--The United States Government may have to pay a large sum to Chinese who have back claims for United States Social Security benefits and pensions that they were unable to collect before the United States and China normalized relations last winter.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 4--Doug DeCinces planted his feet just off third base, pounded his glove and stared intently at Brian Downing. It was the ninth inning, the California Angels had transformed a 9-1 Baltimore breather into a 9-8 breath-stopper, and now they had the bases loaded with two out and Downing, a .326 hitter, at bat.

MILAN, Oct. 3--When the Italians invite the fashion world in for a visit, their hospitality is boundless. Milan, which has bloomed in the last few years as a design center, introduced its fashions for spring and summer 1980 in an atmosphere of efficiency as well as good cheer this week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--President Carter intends to announce his candidacy for a second term on Dec. 4 and set off the next morning on a four-day, nationwide fund-raising tour that is expected to raise some $2 million, campaign officials said today.

The International Business Machines Corporation's record-setting $1 billion of notes and debentures were formally offered to investors yesterday, and the securities, the only such I.B.M. debt on the market, evoked a less than hearty response. Late yesterday afternoon, the underwriters estimated that $200 million remained unsold.

An official of an international Roman Catholic women's group pleaded yesterday for a papal audience, saying that she believed Pope John Paul II could be persuaded to withdraw his opposition to ordaining women as priests.

Tomorrow at 9 P.M., CBS's "Big Shamus, Little Shamus" has its hero, a hotel detective, being kidnapped with a wealthy socialite. It seems the villains are seeking revenge on the woman's father. Does the detective survive? I assume so, but don't know for sure. The episode was not available for viewing. However, judging from last week's premiere of this new series, it probably doesn't matter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said emphatically today that the United States would not alter its policy of refusing to sell military equipment to China.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--The Government's index of producer prices, intended to anticipate future price trends at the retail level, shot up 1.4 percent in September, the largest monthly increase in almost five years, the Labor Department reported today.

OTTAWA, Oct. 9--Canada's first Progressive-Conservative Government in 16 years said at the opening of Parliament today that it would pursue a policy of consultation and cooperation rather than confrontation between the national Government and the 10 provinces.

MANILA, Oct. 9 (Reuters)--Two boatloads of Vietnamese refugees were picked up in the South China Sea last night and early today after they were spotted by United States Navy planes, a Navy spokesman said. ALBANY, Oct. 9 (AP)--Governor Carey has reappointed Justice Louis M. Greenblott of Binghamton to the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court for the Third Department. BALTIMORE, Oct. 9--"It's not an irritation," Chuck Tanner said tonight after the opening game of the 76th World Series was rained out. "It's not a disaster. It's an inconvenience."
JERUSALEM, Oct. 9 (AP)--Electricity went out throughout Israel today as a result of a short circuit at a Tel Aviv power station, officials said.

Back in 1966, a fashion critic noted that the Mme. Gres collection just unveiled in Paris "could have been confused with dozens that she has done in the last decade." Voinovich. George S. Horacek of Seven Hills, who entered his plea in Municipal Court, was charged with the death of Molly Voinovich.

Chester O. French, a longtime Exxon Corporation official who helped create advanced electronic homing missiles for the Army Air Force during World War II and assisted in the first reconstruction of German V-1 and V-2 "buzz" bombs, died yesterday at the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Weston, Conn.
Can a publicity stunt be a genuine news story?

Gifford-Hill Company, a Dallasbased construction material concern, and Amcord Inc., a building products company with headquarters in Newport Beach, Calif., jointly announced yesterday that their boards had approved the previously announced proposed tender offer by Gifford-Hill for all of Amcord's common stock for $34 a share.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP)-- Gold sold for an average $412.78 an ounce at the International Monetary Fund's monthly auction, the agency announced today.

LONDON, Oct. 10--Gold leaped back above the $400 mark today as it became clear that Washington's weekend anti-inflation package had neither restored broad confidence in currencies nor broken the recent speculative fever.
Judge Edith Spurlock Sampson, 76 years old, the first black woman elected to the Illinois bench, died Monday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago.

NEW HAVEN A TREASURE is tucked away in the spacious attic of William and Lucille Celentano's Victorian home. It isn't hidden in grandma's trunk or lying unrecognized beneath accumulated dust. It's the attic area itself.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (Reuters)-- Alfred E. Kahn, chairman of the President's Council of Wage and Price Stability, and the council's director, Robert Russell, said today that a recession would not solve the nation's high inflation rate and called for a continued effort by labor and management to voluntarily restrain wages and prices. They made their pleas in testimony before the House banking subcommittee.
FIRST it was the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation, then the Mostek Corporation, both front-ranking semiconductor companies.

THE least interesting person in Thomas Powers's splendid new book is Richard Helms himself. He was, for 30 years, a dedicated "spook," "a good soldier" who took orders from "one President at a time," ...

NEWARK, Oct. 10--It was a church sale to end all sales. People who had not been in the building in decades returned here today to St. James Roman Catholic Church to reminisce tearfully in its Gothic interior and to remember the baptisms, weddings and funerals they had attended.

THEY came from sunny California to a dark, inhospitable space in New York's garment district. But Jerry Van Deelen and Charles Swerz, partners in Chas. Swerz Associates, a space and lighting design firm, were hardly unhappy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP)--Daniel Minchew, a former aide to Senator Herman E. Talmadge and his chief accuser in the investigation of the Georgia Democrat, received a four-month prison term today for submitting a false $2,289 expense voucher to the Senate.

Harold Fisher, an attorney intimately acquainted with many of New York's political leaders, has resigned as the part-time chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. His replacement had been urged by the City Club and others who found him too remote from the lowly problems of the subways.
JONESTOWN, Guyana--Nearly a year after the deaths of more than 900 Americans here, the commune that Jim Jones built dozes quietly in the tropic sun.

"LIGHT" may never end. "Light" may just go on and on, always harsh, always cold-- this particular "Light" being the monumental work that Kei Takei, a Japanese-born modern dancer, has been choreographing since 1969.

ADOLESCENCE can often be diagnosed by inappropriateness of dress, inability to comprehend reason and a deter mination to turn the brain to jelly by bombarding it with raucous noises. One symptom, however, is incontrovertible proof the stage has arrived:

GARDENING is an attempt at breeding order out of chaos. Viewed in this light, the grace ful terraced garden of flowers, rock and sculpture on Wards Island is close to a masterwork. For the original project seemed to have nothing going for it.
The Knicks placed further emphasis on their rebuilding movement yesterday by putting Glen Gondrezick and John Rudd on waivers.
The changing of the guard on corporate boards is not going entirely according to script.

ATLANTA, Oct. 10 (AP)--The Atlanta Flames of the National Hockey League signed Garry Unger, who was a free agent, to a multiyear contract today, enabling him to compete in the Flames' season opener in Quebec and continue his record streak of consecutive games played.
TRENTON, Oct. 10--The Army Training Center at Fort Dix will remain open for at least 12 to 18 months longer, Clifford L. Alexander, Secretary of the Army, announced today.

TORONTO, Oct. 10--For two periods tonight, the New York Rangers and the Toronto Maple Leafs played exhibition hockey, sluggish and sloppy, with only flashes of the kind of play that makes these two clubs among the most respected in the National Hockey League.

THANKS to the astuteness, energy and longevity of the late Arthur Fiedler, the word "pops," when associated with music in this country, came to stand for easy-to-listen-to symphonic concerts featuring an international mix of classical, operetta and pop selections performed by the Boston Pops Orchestra or one of its imitators.

The Bronx District Attorney's office suffered an apparent setback yesterday in the murder trial of Howard Jacobson, a former race horse trainer and Manhattan real estate entrepreneur, when it was disclosed that the man he is accused of killing had been named posthumously as an unindicted co-conspirator in a multimillion-dollar Federal narcotics case.

LONDON, Oct. 10 (Reuters)--The British Petroleum Company's interest in the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) has risen to 53.1 percent from 52 percent on Dec. 31, following a rise in Sohio's share of Alaskan North Slope oil production to 600,000 barrels a day, after royalties, a B.P. spokesman said. He noted that 53.1 percent was the maximum under B.P.'s 1970 takeover agreement with Sohio.
Autumn storms swept through the New York metropolitan area yesterday, spinning out a freakish combination of thick fog, rain and the season's first snowfalls in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

MAYA Romanoff has earned a reputation as a textile innovator. But his floor cloths, his wall hangings in leather, canvas silk and velvet tapestry and the furniture he has had upholstered in patterned Chinese silk, leather or cotton suede are all meant to be used.
Falling stock prices, along with the abrupt rise in interest rates, has created a dilemma for some of the nearly one million investors who maintian margin accounts at brokerage firms.

J.P. Morgan Company reported yesterday that its earnings in the third quarter rose 10.7 percent from the year-earlier level. This was a slower rate of increase than it achieved in earlier quarters of 1979.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--John Nicholas Brown, a former Assistant Secretary of the Navy and a member of one of Rhode Island's leading families, died last night of an apparent heart attack aboard his yacht in Annapolis, Md. He was 79 years old and was a resident of Providence.

ALGIERS, Oct. 10 (AP)--Algeria will increase sales of refined petroleum products in 1980 to compensate for a cutback in exports of crude oil, the official press agency Algerie Presse Service reported.

HOUSTON, Oct. 10--Officials of the Environmental Protection Agency today announced plans to crack down on communities throughout the country, numbering possibly in the thousands, that have dragged their feet on cleaning up their sewage discharges.

TORONTO, Oct. 10 (AP)--Brascan Ltd. said today that it had bought an additional 250,000 shares of Noranda Mines Ltd. in a continuation of heavy buying that started last Friday when it acquired almost 9 million shares, or about 10 percent of the mining company's outstanding common stock.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--The Federal Government told the nation's colleges and universities today that they could establish "numerical goals" to increase minority enrollment without violating the Supreme Court's ban on strict racial or ethnic quotas in admissions.

THAT familiar artifact, a Chopin recital, was played by Lilian Kallir last night at the 92d Street Y. Building her program around the B-minor Sonata, Miss Kallir also played a pair of nocturnes, six mazurkas, the F-sharp Impromptu and the A-flat Ballade.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--The Senate Finance Committee voted today to extempt oil profits received by states, localities and public colleges and universities from the "windfall" profits tax, a move that will further reduce the dwindling proceeds of the levy by an estimated $4.5 billion or more over 11 years.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 10 (AP)--A former Houston steelworker who suffered brain damage 14 years ago when his 1962 Corvair went out of control and turned over won a $2.4 million judgment from the General Motors Corporation today. The Texas Supreme Court upheld a Houston jury verdict in favor of Harold L. Bryant, 48 years old. The jury found the right rear suspension of Mr. Bryant's car was defectively designed and manufactured.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--New Yorkers threw a gala tonight to thank Congress for helping the city survive its financial crisis, and so many Representatives and Senators clamored for so many of the scarce tickets that the party's headquarters looked like the box office of a Broadway hit the morning after opening night.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 10--The battle against the elements in the World Series began at 7 o'clock this morning when Pat Santarone, chief groundskeeper for the Baltimore Orioles, drove to work in Memorial Stadium from his home in suburban Jacksonville, Md., and found "it was snowing like hell."
FRANKFURT, Oct. 10--Detente on the book front between the United States and the Soviet Union received a setback as the 31st Frankfurt Book Fair opened here today.

METAIRIE, La., Oct. 10 (UPI)--Jefferson Parish teachers formally ratified a new two-year contract today, ending a the longest teacher strike in the nation this year. About 98 percent of the teachers voted to approve the contract. Their strike lasted 26 days.

THE word "attic" means the story above the cornice of a classical facade and refers to the room within the framework of the roof. Whatever its purpose or interior design, the attic has always offered an ideal place for seeking solitude, removed as it is from the mainstream of family life.

The Hughes Television Network will televise some regular-season National Hockey League games as well as the league's All-Star Game and some playoff contests, John Ziegler, N.H.L. president, has announced.
Reaction to the Susan B. Anthony dollar coin has been overwhelmingly unfavorable, with 66 percent of the national population disliking it, according to the latest Gallup poll.

An 11-man boxing team that includes four Pan American Games champions will represent the United States starting tonight in a weeklong competition known as the World Cup championships. The event, which is being held for the first time, is looked upon as a tuneup for next summer's Olympic Games in Moscow.
Despite the stock market tumult of the last few days, Dave Williams, chairman of Alliance Capital Management Corporation, said yesterday that "we plan to stay fully invested in common stocks."
Brokerage house employees were buffeted by an avalanche of orders yesterday as trading on the New York Stock Exchange soared to a record 81.6 million shares.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP)--William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, is liberalizing the bureau's long tradition of harsh punishment for agents who engage in sexual relationships outside marriage.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 10 (UPI) --Soldiers have arrested 120 people in a weeklong campaign to root out sympathizers of the ousted President, Anastasio Somoza Debayle.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 10 (UPI) --A hot air balloon buffeted by winds caught fire and plummeted 2,000 feet to earth today, killing two balloonists as horrified spectators watched.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP)--President Carter will address a $125-a-plate fund-raising event for the District of Columbia Democratic Party on Saturday night. The annual dinner is held in memory of President Kennedy, Robert F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--Lawyers from the American Civil Liberties Union testified today that a proposed law to define the powers and duties of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was "seriously flawed" because the legislation largely relied on the bureau to police its own behavior.
In a severe break that dealers described as one of the worst in market memory, bond prices sank yesterday and some interest rates soared to unprecedented levels in active, nervous trading.

NBC News released yesterday what it said was the complete and unedited transcript of a 52-minute interview with Henry A. Kissinger conducted by David Frost on Oct. 3. It concerns the Nixon Administration's Cambodian policies.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 10 (AP)-- About 15,000 Cambodians fled into Thailand to escape a Vietnamese mortar and artillery attack today as the Phnom Penh regime conceded that more than half the nation's population was in danger of starving.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--A major legislative effort to assist Vietnam veterans was announced today by a bipartisan Congressional group who urged broader assistance in employment, health care and education benefits to men and women who served in the Vietnam war.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP)-- Rosalynn Carter announced a project today to raise $25 million over five years to buy paintings and other historical objects for the White House.

Robert Baudin, whose airborne publicity stunt prompted the evacuation of the United Nations Building and a 27story Manhattan building occupied by a book publisher, was held in $25,000 bail yesterday and ordered to undergo a psychiatric examination.

At least one textile worker was killed and two others were injured yesterday afternoon as a fire swept through a sixstory Brooklyn building. The blaze touched off a series of explosions that rocked the Fort Greene neighborhood and sent two dozen workers scurrying to the street.

Men's professional tennis solved its most immediate problem with the announcement yesterday that Volvo of America would pick up the sponsorship of the Grand Prix tournament, which is being dropped by Colgate after the Masters in New York in January.

PARIS, Oct. 10--The United States and other oil-consuming countries intend to introduce next month a reporting procedure through which they hope to curb soaring energy costs, energy officials disclosed today. The plan is to identify buyers and sellers of oil at levels above the "official" world price.

ROME, Oct. 10 (AP)--Five bandits broke into the apartment of Mordechai Fadlun, a jewel dealer, took him to his office and made off with 66 pounds of gold and gems the victim said were worth $4.2 million, the police reported today.

HILLSDALE, N.Y.--Route 22 is a rustic ribbon that jogs leisurely northward hugging the eastern New York State border. At this hamlet, little more than a hundred miles north of the Bronx, it comes as no surprise to see horses, cows and cornstalks in settings of breathtaking rural splendor.

The partners of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell Co. issued a stunning rebuff yesterday to the outgoing chairman, Walter E. Hanson, and his hand-picked choice for a successor, Charles H. Davison, by passing over Mr. Davison and electing Thomas L. Holton as the top executive in the nation's largest accounting concern.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (Reuters)--The International Harvester Company has begun to see some softening in the truck market, but its truck and agricultural equipment plants continue to operate at or near capacity, Archie R. McCardell, chairman, told a news conference today

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 10--A charge that Peruvian soccer players were paid to "throw" a semifinal game of the 1978 World Cup that enabled Argentina to reach the final instead of Brazil has reopened a lively debate in South America.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 10--A former town employee armed with a shotgun and distraught over being unable to qualify for an apartment in a housing complex held eight female employees hostage in the Town Clerk's office for four and a half hours tonight before releasing them unharmed and surrendering to the police after being assured that his family would have a place to live.

ALBANY, Oct. 10--The New York State Court of Appeals has ruled unanimously here that regulations of the Dime Savings Bank in Manhattan requiring nine days to clear a local check and 21 days to clear an out-of-town check are legal.
SEVERAL floors above the cavernous theater of the newly resurrected Radio City Music Hall, serious business was at hand: a witch was trying to get Snow White to eat a poisonous apple.

WASHNGTON, Oct. 10--A Federal grand jury in Tucson, Ariz., indicted two members of a wealthy and prominent cattle ranching family today on charges of robbing and beating three Mexicans who entered the country illegally in August 1976 in search of work.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP)--Two California brokers were disciplined today by the Securities and Exchange Commission for their roles in failing to alert customers to the real risks in trading transactions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--James T. McIntyre Jr., the Federal budget director, said today that President Carter's next budget, the one on which he is expected to run for re-election, was likely to exceed $600 billion unless there were some cuts in nonmilitary programs.

PEKING, Oct. 10--More than 2,000 students from People's University staged a protest march and sit-in in front of Communist Party headquarters here today to demand the withdrawal of an army artillery unit from their campus.

PARIS, Oct. 10--Reports that the former ruler of the Central African Republic ordered 30 carats of diamonds sent to Valery Giscard d'Estaing were published today in French newspapers, and the opposition Socialist Party called for a parliamentary inquiry.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 10--Somehow the Jets seem to defy the aging process. As the season goes along, they're becoming younger if not better.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser, said today that failure of the Western allies to go ahead with plans for new intermediate-range missile systems in Europe could lead to political intimidation from the Soviet Union "at best, and even war at worst."

Mayor David Vann of Birmingham, Ala., who based his political career on appeals for racial harmony, was defeated Tuesday in an election led by a Councilman trying to become the city's first black Mayor.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 10--For the first time since the United States withdrew its diplomatic recognition, the Chinese Nationalists on Taiwan celebrated their national day today, placing renewed emphasis on self-reliance.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 10--After having been delayed 24 hours by rain, the World Series opened in 41-degree weather tonight and developed into an embarrassing start and frustrating finish for the Pittsburgh Pirates, who were beaten, 5-4, by the Baltimore Orioles at Memorial Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--The Senate majority leader said today that he hoped to be ready to begin debate on the strategic arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union by about Nov. 1, and the Carter Administration promised to give Congress an outline of future military spending plans before the Senate votes on the pact.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--The United States will supply $7 million in emergency food and money to an international effort aimed at saving the lives of millions of Cambodians facing starvation, State Department officials said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--The Carter Administration has met its goal of increasing stockpiles of home heating oil and diesel fuel to 240 million barrels, virtually guaranteeing that there will be no shortage in supplies of the vital fuels this winter, according to a senior member of the White House staff.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--A SenateHouse impasse that threatens payless or reduced-rate paydays for millions in the military and in Federal agencies intensified today as the Senate held firm against a Congressional pay increase and strict limits on Federal funds for abortions.

Elmendorf Farm's Syncopate charged from last place in a field of six horses to win the $53,950 Boojum Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 10 (AP)--A California liquor law may stand in the way of the proposed $630 million sale of the Howard Johnson hotel-restaurant chain to a British brewery, a state lawyer said today.

Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California yesterday made his first serious incursion of the campaign season into New York City on his quest for the Presidency, laughing away the characterization of him as "Governor Moonbeam" and proposing that oil companies be put under Federal control.

The man who has quietly taken control of the Liberal Paarty over the last few years, Raymond B. Harding, publicly proclaimed his leadership role last night and said it was time for liberal politicians to "become stubborn."

BALTIMORE, Oct. 10--Even after a hit, two walks, and a double-play ball that did not become a double play, the Pittsburgh Pirates had their chance to escape the first inning of the World Series without a Baltimore run.

LONDON, Oct. 10--"Bugatti" means "cars" to most people, but the family name first achieved fame with Carlo Bugatti, the designer of flamboyant furniture. Carlo begat Ettore, the automobile designer, and Rembrandt, a successful sculptor of animal bronzes who committed suicide at the age of 30.

The dollar fell sharply on foreign exchange markets at home and abroad yesterday as enthusiasm for the dollarsupport program announced last weekend waned and the price of gold soared back over the $400-an-ounce level.

TUCSON, Ariz., Oct. 10 (AP)--Gov. Bruce E. Babbitt of Arizona knew of the potential for release of lethal radioactive tritium from a factory two weeks before he declared an emergency and ordered a state takeover of the plant, his executive assistant confirmed today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--The Government, in its first action to protect worker fertility and the health of the unborn under the occupational health and safety law, today cited the American Cyanamid Company for violations of health standards at a plant in Willow Island, W.Va.

ALBUQUERQUE, Oct. 10--President Carter met here tonight with 10 Western Governors to assure them that his new energy program would not usurp their authority over the water and natural resources in their states.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 10--The Lebanese Government announced today that it was taking extra security measures in the country's northern region after the murder of five members of the family of a former President in a wave of kidnappings by rival Christian factions.

The International Business Machines Corporation's $1 billion financing, begun with such fanfare last week, ended yesterday with the largest underwriting loss in Wall Street's history. Investment bankers estimated that the overall loss may have run as high as $30 million.
TORONTO, Oct. 10--The Toronto Stock Exchange, picking up the shock waves generated by sharply rising interest rates, again followed United States markets sharply downward today.

A 200,000-square-foot Neiman-Marcus specialty store will occupy part of a 60-story tower to be built on North Michigan Avenue, Chicago's fashion shopping area, it was announced. The $120 million project, scheduled to begin early next year, will also include condominiums and office space.
BRISBANE Australia, Oct. 10 (AP) --A little-known American, Matt Mitchell, defeated top-seeded Geoff Masters of Australia today, 7-5, 6-2, in a second-round match of the South Pacific Tennis Classic.

Local legislators, town planners and citizens criticized what they called the big-city orientation and insensitivity of the Tristate Regional Planning Commission yesterday before a gubernatorial task force considering whether to abolish, change or strengthen the commission.

SEATTLE, Oct. 10 (Reuters)--The Boeing Company said today that it had established a $1.25 billion standby credit agreement with a group of commercial banks. Boeing said the agreement provided for the credit to become available at the time of peak program investment in its 757 and 767 jets.

BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 10--The Conservative Party's annual conference today weathered the threat of a debilitating split over Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Zimbabwe Rhodesia policy, but only after an outbreak of heckling and recriminations that shattered the usual decorum of Tory gatherings.
CAIRO, Oct. 10--President Anwar elSadat was quoted today as having said that Saudi Arabia was experiencing popular resentment over the lavish life style of its ruling family.

THE succah at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue may be indoors, but it is exposed to the sky by a roof that opens with an electric switch. JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 10--The Government released 2,000 prisoners from the prison island of Buru today. Many of them had been held without trial for 13 years.

A committee of the New York City Bar Association has recommended the adoption of a new professional rule--the first of its kind anywhere in the country--that would require each of the city's 45,000 lawyers to donate 30 to 50 hours a year in free or low-cost legal service to needy individuals or public causes.

Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California finished his first full week of campaigning yesterday with mixed results in his struggle for identity as a Democratic alternative to President Carter and Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts.

Serious consideration is being given to a plan to create additional alternative high schools in New York City to cope with the soaring dropout rate, a Board of Education official said yesterday.
Four prominent blacks expressed concern yesterday that the debate among blacks over the Palestine Liberation Organization might seriously damage the black movement.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 17 (Reuters)--The European Economic Community Commission said today that it was too early to specify what measures it might take against rising United States exports of petrochemicals and man-made fibers to member nations of the community.
The 12th annual Morristown Antiques Fair opens today with 100 dealers showing a wide variety of collectibles. The fair continues through Sunday evening.

PARIS, Oct. 17 (Reuters)--France and China signed new economic, cultural and technological cooperation agreements today that may broaden the scope of relations between the two countries up to the year 2000.

The United States Trust Company, whose main business has been to manage other people's money, reported a 21 percent drop in thirdquarter operating income yesterday and said net income had dropped 70 percent, primarily as a result of losses from its investment activities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI)--Representative Charles C. Diggs Jr. was given permission today to take a 20-day tour of Africa and Europe while awaiting a ruling on his appeal of a payroll kickback conviction.
Dr. Frank R. Smith, a gynecologist who had been associated with New York and Roosevelt Hospitals, died Monday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 83 years old.
UNITED STATES NAVAL BASE, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, Oct. 17--Hampered by a sometimes driving rainstorm, 1,800 marines in battle gear landed at this lonely American outpost on Communist soil this morning.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 17 (Reuters)-- A British freighter that collided with a Greek ship in the Dardanelles this morning has been run aground near Intepe on the Anatolian coast, the Turkish radio said.

Federal agents and New York detectives yesterday began questioning Michele Sindona, the Italian financier who had been missing for two and a half months. But they said they could not immediately judge whether he had been kidnapped or had dropped out of sight intentionally to avoid trial on charges of bank fraud.
PEKING, Oct. 17--A dissident, Fu Yuehua, was put on trial today on charges of having disrupted public order and of having falsely accused a Communist Party official of raping her.
PARIS, Oct.17--A funny thing happened at the end of the fashion shows for spring here. Nobody clapped.

SAN DIEGO, Oct. 17 (AP)--The City of San Diego is raising the San Diego Padres' office space rent by 86 percent and says the National League baseball club must agree to the new lease by Monday or face eviction from San Diego Stadium.

Problems in developing the space shuttle have forced a two-year postponement of the 1982 Galileo mission to orbit Jupiter and to study its atmosphere, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17--A program extending tax credits for high home heating costs to families with incomes of up to $22,000 a year was approved today by the Senate Finance Committee.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa.--The myth of "big labor" lives on, even though the average worker, including union members, has made little or no progress in his buying power in recent years and the United States labor movement recently has lost several major political battles.
Hit by increasing fuel costs and price wars on some key routes, two major airlines yesterday reported sharply lower third-quarter earnings.
DETROIT THERE was a period--the Ed wardian period--when the American painter John Singer Sargent (1856-1925) was looked on by people of power and influence as one of the greatest artists of his time.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17--Late this evening, the Chrysler Corporation submitted a revised financial rescue plan to the Treasury Department that seeks $750 million in Federal loan guarantees. The revised proposal requests assistance within the limits outlined a month ago by G. William Miller, Secretary of the Treasury.
An 8-year-old boy, his voice soft but steady, told how he had seen robbers shoot his father to death in front of the family's Brooklyn grocery store.

Governor Carey yesterday named Richard Ravitch, a wealthy builder, as chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 17 (UPI)--A light earthquake jolted metropolitan Los Angeles today, two days after a bigger tremor that injured more than 60 people in Imperial County, 200 miles away.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17--President Carter today signed legislation creating a new Department of Education at a White House ceremony attended by 200 applauding education officials.

ROANOKE, Va., Oct. 17 (AP)--Clem Dixon Johnston, a former president of the Chambers of Commerce of the United States and Virginia, died yesterday at a Roanoke hospital. He was 82 years old.

The racing career of Noble Dancer II, an $8,222 purchase that won nearly a million dollars as a leading grass-course competitor has ended because of a leg injury incurred during a workout at Belmont Park. The 7-year-old horse ruptured ligaments on Monday, and efforts were under way yesterday to save him for stud service, though the feeling was that he would have to be destroyed.

The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's largest producer of photographic products, said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings had risen 20 percent to a record $285.9 million, or $1.78 a share, from $238.1 million, or $1.48 a share, in the comparable period last year.

A LOT of people still want to be writers. Writing may not have quite the cachet that it had when Dickens, Tolstoy and Victor Hugo were around, but it is still pretty nice to be known everywhere and instantaneously as "the famous author."

BALTIMORE, Oct. 17--Everyone and everything was in place. The television camera was mounted in the center of the Orioles' clubhouse, the champagne was nearby, and the President of the United States was there to offer congratulations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI)--The Agriculture Department said today that Moscow had bought another 787,000 metric tons of United States grain from private traders. WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP)--New home construction increased 4.2 percent nationwide in September as the industry continued to show considerably more strength than had been predicted, the Commerce Department said today.

With oil shares leading the way, stock prices registered a token advance yesterday after seven straight declines. But analysts noted that volume remained well below recent levels and interpreted this as a sign of investor caution.

LONDON, Oct. 17 (AP)--England defeated Northern Ireland, 5-1, today in Belfast and moved a step closer to gaining the finals of the European Cup of Nations soccer tournament.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 17 (AP)--An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who had been suspended for allegedly stealing money intended for informers and discussing participation in a theft ring officially resigned today.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 17 (AP)--Leaders of 5,000 Cleveland teachers rejected a wage increase of 6 percent tonight, paving the way for an immediate strike.

ABC-TV is entering the 80's with full confidence it can hold its own in the marketplace invaded by new communications technologies because of the network's long experience as a provider of entertainment and informational programming, Frederick S. Pierce, president of ABC Television, said yesterday.

At a time when such personal data as credit information and police files are increasingly being made available to Americans, no state allows adopted persons unrestricted access to their records despite a large number of requests from adults seeking to learn their histories.

ROME, Oct. 17--Two more members of a known organized crime family were arrested last night in Palermo, the Sicilian capital, on suspicion of involvement in the disappearance of Michele Sindona.

New rules for handling the annual Pulitzer Prize awards in journalism, the arts and letters were announced yesterday by the Pulitzer Prize board.

THE American Place Theater, which works mostly in live drama, is filling the lunch hour laughably on film these weekdays.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17--A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee voted unanimously today to recommend $35 million in additional emergency aid to help Cambodians avoid famine.

HARTFORD, Oct. 17--Gov. Ella T. Grasso announced emergency fuel aid proposals today that would include $22 million in aid to the working poor, a doubling of a $3 million program of energy conservation loans to homeowners and the granting of new powers and money for municipalities to prevent housing abandonment because of higher fuel costs this winter.

BONN, Oct. 17 (AP)--New West German private direct investments abroad rose 23.7 percent in the first half of 1979 while foreign investments in West Germany climbed only 4.6 percent, the Economics Ministry reported today. WASHINGTON, Oct. 17--The State Department for the first time since the establishment of diplomatic relations rebuked China publicly today in a human rights case. It said the United States was "surprised and disappointed" by the severity of a prison term given a dissident in Peking yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Oct. 17 (AP)--Bank Leumi, Israel's largest bank, settled a labor dispute today that had closed 300 branches for two weeks and disrupted financial transactions throughout the country. The world doesn't normally take much notice when a new military government pops up in El Salvador. Central America's most densely populated country has been under military rule of one kind or another for the past 45 years. Since a peasant uprising in 1932 badly frightened the few families that control much of El Salvador's wealth, repressive force has been the only response to demands for social reform.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17--Robert S. Strauss, President Carter's special Middle East envoy, said today that he planned to fly to London next week for another round of talks with the chief Egyptian and Israeli negotiators. In her sixth month of pregnancy, Janine Ricozzi, a 28 year-old Westchester County woman, began to develop swollen ankles, a condition that is very common among pregnant women. PARIS, Oct. 18 (Reuters) Prime Minister Raymond Barre was admitted to a hospital today for a medical examination, but a bulletin said his condition was not serious.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist denied a stay of execution today for a convicted killer, Jesse Bishop, who is scheduled to die in Nevada's gas chamber on Monday.

THE story of the gypsy moth is a typical tale of man's good intentions gone astray. In an attempt to create a hearty strain of silkworm capable of survival in New England, a scientist imported the gypsy moth from Europe in 1869. His intention was to hybridize it with the less hearty silkworm, the basis of the silk industry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP)--Sara Elisabeth Lister yesterday became the Army's general counsel. She is the second woman to serve as the Army's top civilian lawyer. WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 The civil war in Afghanistan has reached a stalemate, United States Government analysts say, in which the army of President Hafizullah Amin controls Kabul and a handful of other cities, while insurgent forces operate with impunity in about half the country.
AGLARING distinction of "Freedom Road" is that it takes Muhammad Ali, certainly one of the more vibrant personalities of this century, and makes him dull. Years in the making.
New York City accounted for 86 percent of all youngsters arrested in the state for certain violent crimes during the first year of a stricter juvenile justice law.

Patricia Beth Kallman and Robert V. Gaulin, New York lawyers, were married yesterday at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N.Y. Associate Judge Jacob D. Fuchsberg of the State Court of Appeals performed the ceremony. The bride is with the law firm of

Dick Howser met with George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, last August to arrange a game next spring against Howser's Florida State University team. Howser admitted last night, after Steinbrenner had named him manager of the team, that he was "awed" by the fact that he would be managing the Yankees, not coaching Florida State, in that game.

LAKE BUENA VISTA, FLA., Oct. 28 (AP) George Burns and Ben Crenshaw combined for a final-round 65 and a four-round total of 255 that broke par by 33 strokes and won the National Team golf Championship today.
IT isn't often done, but there is a way for owners of summer homes held for investment to exchange residences without exposing themselves to inordinately high taxes.
About 2,000 antinuclear demonstrators gathered in the rain yesterday in front of the World Trade Center to hear speakers decry corporate investment in nuclear power.

The governors of three states have created a crisis for hospitals and research laboratories by refusing to store any more nuclear junk. Three-fifths of the junk, officially called "low-level radioactive waste," comes from the nuclear power industry, chiefly in the form of contaminated clothing, equipment, filters and sludge.

To construct a bridge across Long Island Sound linking Long Island with the New England mainland could cost as much as $1.4 billion and provide employment for 18,000 people, according to a study released by the New York State Department of Transportation.

The New York Stock Exchange, which survived the devastating crash of 1929, the subsequent formation of the Securities and Exchange Commission and cycle after cycle of good markets and bad markets, is now facing its toughest challenge: whether it will modernize fast enough to forestall being replaced, and by a computer system not of its own design.
Fred P. Murphy, the honorary chairman of Grolier Inc., who led his company into business enterprises beyond the reference book field, died Saturday at his home in Stamford, N.Y. He was 90 years old.
SOMERS, Conn. After 42 years in prison, bitterly struggling for vindication and freedom, the prospect of imminent release leaves John A. Palm unmoved.

A week ago, the Washington Redskins used a rugged defensive effort to down the Philadelphia Eagles and move into contention in the National Football Conference's Eastern Division. Yesterday, the Redskins got a strong dose of defensive medicine from the New Orleans Saints, who won, 14-10, in Washington.
Approximately 100 members of two Hasidic sects clashed last night in a Williamsburg, Brooklyn, synagogue in a dispute apparently growing out of a fight between two of their members in Israel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 In communities scattered all across the country, spurred on by utilities, conservationminded citizens are saving water and their good deed is rewarded with higher rates and higher water bills.

THE second "Ballet at the Beacon" program Saturday after noon at the Beacon Theater offeted some interesting novelties. The good turnout suggested again that a mixed program of excerpts with foreign and American dancers appeals strongly to the ballet public.

SEOUL, South Korea, Monday, Oct. 29 Behind the scenes of official mourning, an urgent debate has begun here on how, and with whom, to fill the gap left by the death of President Park Chung Hee, the tough and autocratic man who came to power following a coup in 1961 and in recent years ruled this nation of 39 million people almost single-handedly.

PISCATAWAY, N.J., Oct. 28 It was the first time since the Nets' season-opening victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers that the New Jersey coach, Kevin Loughery, had worn anything other then a sullen expression following a game.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 28 (Reuters) Employees of Iran's oil industry threatened today to cut crude-oil exports to the United States unless Washington agreed to extradite the Shah. The Shah is in a New York hospital. Doctors removed his gall bladder on Wednesday and said he had a 50-50 chance of surviving cancer of the lymph glands.

JAMES BAY, Quebec, Oct. 28 A modest 333 megawatts of electric power, enough, officials say, to operate 220,000 toasters simultaneously and continuously, are now coursing through 650 miles of new transmission lines from this bleak northern wilderness along La Grande river to the south.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28 Not since Charlie Conerly was the Giants' quarterback had the Giants beaten the Los Angeles Rams. Not since Dwight D. Eisenhower was President had they beaten the Rams out here.

The Reader's Digest has made an agreement with Berkley Publishing Corporation, the paperback publisher, to bring the contents of the Reader's Digest to a mass-market audience in book form. It is the first time the material has been made available to a mass-market publisher.
The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly "Lotto" drawing were 27, 38, 8, 24, 37 and 19. The supplementary number was 40.
Carol M. Singer and Daniel Bricklin were married yesterday in Temple Beth El in Sudbury, Mass., by Rabbi Lawrence Kushner.

CONCORD, Mass., Oct. 28 (AP) A single-engine plane carrying a family of four crashed into an unoccupied house near the center of Concord late today, killing the pilot's 12-year-old daughter. The pilot, his wife and another daughter were seriously injured.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct.28 Two proposed state constitutional amendments one that would limit school busing for racial balance and one that would impose a ceiling on spending by state and local governments appear to have overwhelming support among voters.

Carolyn Sue Klaiman, a lawyer with the Criminal Defense Division of the Legal Aid Society in Brooklyn, and Warren Kent Racusin, an associate with the New York law firm of Schulte McGoldrick, were married at noon yesterday in the Chanticler in Millburn, N.J. Rabbi Reuben Levine performed the ceremony.

LHASA, Tibet Living Buddhas were once ensconced in mystic splendor in the temples of Tibet, enthroned and worshiped at a distance. Nowadays it is easy to have a cup of tea or a chat with some of those who stayed behind when the Dalai Lama fled.

ISADORA DUNCAN'S ghost haunted the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday night. The program the second of the concerts arranged by Annabelle Gamson under the title "From Isadora to Pilobolus" featured solos to Russian music and there were three new works.
TEL AVIV, Oct. 28 The Israeli Cabinet decided today that a settlement that the Supreme Court has ruled was illegal would be moved to a new site on the occupied West Bank.

New orders for machine tools in September rose 69 percent from the yearearlier level. Factors in the strong rise included a surge of orders from overseas and strong domestic demand from such sources as the automobile and aerospace industries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) About 500 people gathered in front of the White House today to call attention to the nearly 2,500 Americans still listed as missing in Vietnam, according to the United States Park Police.
Dancers of the American Ballet Theater have voted unanimously to rejest the company's latest offer of a 22 percent package increase over three years. With no negotiating sessions
