On the streets of the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, they are indistinguishable. The Satmar Hasidim and the Belz Hasidim dress in similar black gabardine coats and felt hats. They shun the modern world and immerse themselves in the practice of Jewish law and custom.

Interest rates on residential mortgages continued to climb, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation reported yesterday as it announced the results of its weekly purchase of loans from savings and loan associations and other housing lenders. The average yield on the $24.3 million of mortgages it bought increased to a record 13.363 percent from 12.836 percent last week.
WASHINGTON "So many decisions come into play, it's like a mosaic," Heinz J. Eiermann was saying the other day in his cubicle of an office in a drab Federal building near the Capitol.

Puerto Rico International Airlines resumed service yesterday after being grounded by the Government for three days because of "deficiencies" uncovered in inspections of its operations ordered after a fatal crash in St. Croix, V.I., last July.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 With President Carter in attendance last night, the Vienna State Opera gave the second of its series at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

The Civil Aeronautics Board announced yesterday that it had approved and sent to the White House a bid by Pan American World Airways to take over National Airlines, apparently clearing the way for Pan Am to become the nation's third-largest airline.
BRUSSELS Official Europe has discovered the three-martini lunch.

Arab groups in the United States have started a new campaign to forge a broad political alliance with blacks, from the community level to major civil rights organizations and politicians, as part of an effort to change American policy on the Middle East.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., Oct. 29 Students ignore it and educators would rather not talk about it. But on many college campuses, building maintenance is declining even faster than student enrollment.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 29 The proportion of women holding jobs in this Fairfield County city has increased sharply in the past five years, but women, blacks and Hispanic persons still lag far behind white men at the upper rungs of the job ladder, according to an employment survey made public today by the Stanford Commission on Human Rights.

A sex discrimination suit charging that the New York City Police Department promotes female officers to the rank of detective ahead of male officers "regardless of merit" was filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

Tai Lee Wing, 28 years old, was fatally shot Sunday evening by one of two holdup men who entered the China King Restaurant, 1965 University Avenue in the Bronx, the police said. They said the robbers had fled the restaurant, in the Morris Heights section, without taking any money.

EVERY recent opinion poll about public education has cited dis cipline as the most serious problem and violence as a constant threat to teacher and student safety. A new study of the issue calls these fears exaggerated, and the disciplinary steps taken to combat school crime often ineffective and irrational.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) The conventional long-term, fixed-interest mortgage could fall victim to inflation and volatile interest rates, Jay Janis, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said today.
PARIS, Oct. 29 More than 1,000 young Congolese, 600 of them between the ages of 10 and 15, have reportedly been sent to Cuba for training that will last up to 15 years.

WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 29 An 18yearold former high school student was arrested here today following a party Friday night at the home of his parents in which eight students became violently ill when they inhaled phencyclidine hydrochloride, a drug known as "angel dust," which they apparently believed was cocaine.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 The Supreme Court decided today that Charles (Boobie) Clark, a former running back for the Cincinnati Bengals, would have to defend himself against a $500,000 lawsuit brought by a former Denver Bronco player whose neck he allegedly fractured in an end-zone incident on Sept. 16, 1973.

An "upset and unhappy" Willie Mays had a last-minute talk with Commissioner Bowie Kuhn yesterday and then affirmed his decision to work for a casino hotel, though it meant severing his ties with the New York Mets.

TOKYO, Oct. 29 (AP) Japan's exports of color television sets in September totaled 374,347 units, down 17.8 percent from September 1978, but up 9.1 percent from August 1979, the Electronics Industries Association said today.

ALBANY LOOKING slightly out of context, a piece of an "A" train, a New York City subway car marked "Court Street-Boro Hall" sat before the New York State Museum here last Friday, and there was much rejoicing.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 The Northrop Corporation has asked a Federal judge here to prevent the McDonnell Douglas Corporation from unilaterally offering to foreign companies contracts to manufacture certain parts of the F/ A-18A Hornet fighter plane that Northrop had agreed to provide.
Alvin Hampel, the worldwide creative chief of Benton Bowles, has decided at age 52 and after 10 years with the same company that he wants to do something else. After his resignation was announced...

LONDON, Oct. 29 Commonwealth leaders have begun an informal but intensive diplomatic effort in hopes of finding some way to break the logjam in the Lancaster House negotiations on Zimbabwe Rhodesia, which entered their eighth week today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (Reuters) The First National Bank of Chicago and the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago raised their prime rate today to 15 percent from 15 percent. The move was initiated by Citibank on Friday and was followed by the First Pennsylvania Bank and the Manufacturers National Bank of Detroit.
Stefan Congrat-Butler, a lexicographer and the compiler of a pioneer directory, "Translation and Translators," died of leukemia Saturday in his home in Manhattan. He was in his mid-60's.
Wesley Walker, the most significant player on the Jets, averaging almost 25 yards a catch, will miss at least four games with a sprained right knee.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 29 The governors of six Northeastern states met here today with more than 250 labor and business leaders in an attempt to recruit their help in combating the region's energy problems.

Long-term bonds of the Municipal Assistance Corporation of New York State were priced yesterday to yield 8 7/8 percent. This was well above the 7 5/8 percent set in a M.A.C. bond sale in August and the highest rate of return on these tax-exempt bonds in three and a half years.
Treasury bill rates in the Government's weekly auction declined yesterday for the first time since the Federal Reserve moved to tighten credit early this month.
The Rev. Walter A. Reilly, former headmaster of the St. Ignatius Loyola School at 50 East 89th Street, died Sunday at a nursing home in White Plains after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

LOUISVILLE, Ky. It's been called "the kissing campaign," and it's easy to see why. John Y. Brown Jr., Kentucky's Democratic candidate for Governor, and his wife of seven months, Phyllis George, constantly hug and kiss like newlyweds on the campaign trail. And everybody in Kentucky, it seems, wants to kiss the former Miss America turned television personality.

Despite the attempted disruption by pickets outside protesting nuclear power, the New York Stock Exchange marked Black Tuesday yesterday--the 50th anniversary of the great Wall Street crash of 1929--as just another day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 About 200 Hispanic-American political, business and other leaders met at the State Department today for a daylong conference on foreign policy with an emphasis on inter-American affairs.

BRENT ELLIS is no stranger to New York audiences, but it wasn't until Thursday night that he made his debut with the Metropolitan Opera. The 33-yearold baritone, a native of Kansas City, Mo., appeared as Silvio in Leoncavallo's "Pagliacci."

OF all the earth's ups and downs, the mountains and ocean trenches, the bulging equator and flattened poles, few are so subtle or more difficult to measure and map than the irregularities in the magnetic field of the earth's surface.

QUITO, Ecuador, Oct. 29 Personal antagonism between the President of Ecuador and his former mentor, the head of Congress, has paralyzed the new Government that rousingly returned this country to democracy two months ago after nine years of dictatorship.

SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Oct. 30--About 2 A.M. Saturday, an American officer put through a phone call to the United States Ambassador to South Korea, William H. Gleysteen Jr., to tell him that President Park Chung Hee had been killed.
The Lexington School for the Deaf, closed for four weeks by a faculty strike, reopened yesterday, but many of the teachers who ratified an agreement late Sunday night were still unhappy.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Oct. 29 (Reuters) The Keystone Foods Corporation said its Cattle Development Corporation subsidiary had entered into a two-year $85 million credit agreement to finance its cattle management program.
HONG KONG, Oct. 29 (Reuters) Illegal immigration into Hong Kong from China has reached its highest level since May, with more than 9,500 arrested this month, the police said today.

With an official welcome from New York University to "academic partnership," the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion dedicated its $7.5 million New York school yesterday. The five-story Brookdale Center, a blockfront on West Fourth Street from Broadway to Mercer Street, adjoins the university's campus east of Washington Square.

Two trends are now discernible in the Soviet Union's efforts to use Afghanistan as the primary base for Soviet military and political operations in Southwest Asia. One is the establishment of army and air bases near the Iranian frontier.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 The Supreme Court agreed today to resolve a question of increasing commercial importance in an era when new life forms can be readily created in the laboratory: whether the patent laws allow patents for living organisms.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 A private antitrust suit ended today, 19 years after it was filed and three years after a Federal district judge dismissed it for failure to prosecute. The Supreme Court refused the original plaintiff's request to overturn the dismissal and allow the case to proceed to trial.

Officials at the Brookdale Hospital Medical Center, 1275 Linden Boulevard and Rockaway Parkway in Brooklyn, issued a plea yesterday that persons with B-positive blood volunteer to aid a 16-year-old Queens youth with leukemia.

MARION, Ill., Oct. 29 The president of the United Mine Workers of America, Arnold Miller, today reiterated his support for Senator Edward M. Kennedy for President and his criticism of President Carter for allegedly failing to promote the use of coal.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a state can favor widows over widowers in awarding death benefits under state workers' compensation laws.

Men are greatly overrepresented in television's dramatic programs in rela tion to the actual national population, and women, minorities, juveniles and the elderly are underrepresented, according to a study of network programming conducted for the Screen Actors Guild.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 The Senate today passed by voice vote a bill that would encourage families to adopt "hardto-place" children now trapped in the limbo of foster care those who are handicapped, nonwhite or beyond babyhood.

Gustave W. Iser, an architect who practiced in New York for many years designing apartment projects and religious and institutional buildings, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Hollywood, Fla. He was 83 years old.

A memorial service for Norman Lewis, an abstractionist painter and teacher at the Art Students League, will be held at 2:30 P.M. on Thursday in St. Peter's Church, at East 54th Street and Lexington Avenue. Mr. Lewis died in New York on Aug. 27 at the age of 70.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 Under guidelines made public today by a Congressional advisory committee, Secret Service protection will begin Jan. 11 for certain declared Presidential candidates, They are those who have raised at least $1 million in compliance with Federal election laws or have received at least 10 percent of the total votes cast in two consecutive primaries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) President Carter's campaign committee today filed a complaint with the Federal Communications Commission charging the three major television networks with wrongfully refusing to sell him air time for a political speech.

Just how dubious can be seen in a recent speech by McGeorge Bundy that should get more attention in Washington and Western Europe.
TEL AVIV, Oct. 29 (AP) The Israeli police have arrested 43 suspects, 13 of them soldiers, as members of a ring accused of supplying stolen army weapons and ammunition to Arab villages in Israel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--President Carter plans to announce tomorrow the nomination of Shirley Mount Hufstedler, a Federal judge in California, as Secretary of the newly created Department of Education, Administration officials said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) Jane Fonda, the actress, and her husband, Tom Hayden, lost a court appeal today on a Freedom of Information Act request that the Government release intelligence reports about their activities.

Heating conservation tips: 1. Insulate your brain. Your brain is like a thermostat. When it detects that the temperature has fallen to 60 degrees Fahrenheit, it automatically cuts off heat to the body.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 (AP) A man and a woman, trapped by flames on an 11th-floor ledge of their luxury apartment building, screamed for help and then leaped to their deaths with their dog, the authorities said today. A third resident died of smoke inhalation.

Photosynthesis, the biological procase by which green plants store the energy of the sun in the form of complex chemicals, is the ultimate basis of all life, including most of the energy sources on which man depends.

FOUR physicists, including the former director of the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, where the first atomic bomb was developed, have questioned reports that a nuclear accident occurred near the southern Ural Mountains of the Soviet Union in late 1957 or early 1958.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 The First National Bank of Chicago signed an agreement with China today that makes the bank a matchmaker for foreign companies seeking investment opportunities in China.

WASHINGTON WORKING from cluttered quarters in a red-brick building near the White House, a team of manage ment planners is giving final form to the new Department of Education, an agency that will begin life early next year with serious limitations on its mission.

BAN KAENG, Thailand, Oct. 28 For the second time, a bright-eyed 18year-old Cambodian woman has escaped from Cambodia to a refugee camp in Thailand, and once again her brother has rushed here from Paris in the hope of being allowed to take her home with him.
BOSTON The proposed recodification of the Federal Criminal Code sponsored by Senator Edward M. Kennedy and Representative Robert F. Drinan is being rushed to passage without public scrutiny.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Oct. 29 (Reuters) Thousands of metalworkers went on strike here today for higher pay, labor sources said. Union representatives said 170,000 metalworkers heeded a strike call made last night. But the regional labor office said only 30,000 failed to turn up for the morning shift.

The police arrested 1,045 antinuclear protesters yesterday after they attempted unsuccessfully to shut down the New York Stock Exchange by linking arms and blocking entrances to the exchange building on the 50th anniversary of the historic stock market crash of 1929.

The regional office of the National Labor Relations Board in Newark said yesterday that it was distributing a record $640,000 in back pay to 46 Hartz Mountain Corporation employees in Jersey City who were dismissed in a 1974 union organizing dispute.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 Today, on the 50th anniversary of the stock market crash, the Joint Economic Committee of Congress asked some all-stars of the economics profession whether the events that ushered in the Great Depression could happen again.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 29 The mayoral runoff election tomorrow between a black City Councilman and a white lawyer accused of "waving the bloody shirt of racism" has split this city's electorate along racial lines and, in the view of one political pollster, brought racial animosities here to their highest pitch since the civil rights demonstrations of 1963.
ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 26 It was a typical day in Turkey.
NL Industries yesterday reported a 38.3 percent rise in profits for the third quarter, and Ray C. Adam, chairman, said all operating groups had contributed to the record performance.

After delaying the start of their seasons for two months, following a dispute with Actors Equity over new work codes for showcase productions, most Off Off Broadway theaters have decided to proceed with their fall productions.
Prof. Mendor T. Brunetti, a teacher of Romance languages at New York University for 54 years before his retirement in 1978, died Saturday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 85 years old.

ASPIRIN, hailed as a "wonder drug" when it was first introduced 80 years ago, is today a drug of ever-expanding uses. By turning its main drawback the ability to cause bleeding to medi cal advantage, new research has revealed that aspirin has potential life-saving effects for persons in danger of heart attacks, strokes and other disorders caused by blood clots.

Steel production amounted to 2.406 million tons in the week ended Oct. 27, a decrease of 2 percent from the preceding week's 2.454 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The Industry's production used 83.2 percent of capacity...

If Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith wishes to settle a class-action suit brought by New York customers involving the firm's former practice of writing checks on accounts in California banks, it must pay them damages, a state court judge ruled last week.

While there is virtually no organized opposition to a state constitutional amendment doubling the bonding limits of the New York State Job Development Authority, its supporters are concerned that the measure will be defeated by voters who react negatively to dollar signs on the ballot.

TOKYO, Oct. 29 A continuing deadlock in the governing Liberal Democratic Party over demands for the resignation of Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira raised a possibility tonight that Parliament might have to postpone the election of a head of government, normally a procedural formality, when the new House of Representatives convenes tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 Senator Edward M. Kennedy authorized the formation today of a "Kennedy for President" committee and announced that he would officially declare his candidacy on Nov. 7.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct.29 (AP) The Consolidated Rail Corporation has announced that it plans to reduce rates by about 5 percent for more than threefourths of its piggyback freight traffic, subject to Interstate Commerce Commission approval.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 29 President Carter, stepping up his campaign for a tax on oil industry "windfall" profits, appealed today to a gathering of Northeastern governors and energy officials to help prevent what he said could become "a trillion-dollar giveaway" to the oil companies.

The Exxon Corporation announced that it had reached a definitive agreement to acquire the balance of the Reliance Electric Company's stock that it had not already acquired under a $1.2 billion tender offer announced last September.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) The Government today gave up its effort to achieve a negotiated settlement with the Chicago school board and formally recommended that a desegregation suit be filed.

Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's investigation into the latest Billy Martin episode is continuing and could be concluded in the next "day or two," a spokesman for Kuhn said yesterday. However, the commissioner's findings will come too late to save Martin's job as manager of the Yankees, as Martin's lawyer had hoped.

ATLANTA, Oct. 29 (AP) Seattle used three fourth-down conversions in downing the Atlanta Falcons, 31-28, tonight in a National Football League game, and Jim Zorn, the Seahawk quarterback, said, "We don't call them gambles."

Representatives of New York City business and financial interests appealed yesterday for the construction of the Westway, contending that the proposed sunken artery between the Battery and 42d Street would generate employment, produce revenue and improve the quality of life.

Congress has it in its power, perhaps today, to decide whether America will, in a kind of tantrum, turn its back on the world's poor countries. The issue is United States support for the World Bank and other international lending agencies that it helped create. An emotional House would cripple their aid. Only cooler Senate heads can thwart such recklessness.

CAIRO, Oct. 29 (UPI) The Defense Ministers of Egypt and Israel, Gen. Kamal Hassan Ali and Ezer Weizman, will meet tomorrow at the United Statesmanned electronic monitoring station in Sinai, the Middle East News Agency said today. The agency did not explain the purpose of the meeting but it was believed to be related to arrangements for Israel's withdrawal from Sinai.

TEL AVIV, Oct. 29 Prime Minister Menachem Begin sought unsuccessfully today to offer the post of Foreign Minister to a fellow Cabinet member and said later that for the time being he would keep the portfolio himself.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) The Environmental Protection Agency today announced a temporary ban on most uses of the pesticide DBCP.

PARIS, Oct. 29 The Palestine Liberation Organization has made important diplomatic gains in Western Europe in the last few weeks, including an announcement today of "political recognition" by the Government of Italy.

Stock prices virtually collapsed yesterday, swept downward with gigantic losses in the most disastrous trading day in the stock market's history. Billions of dollars in open market values were wiped out as prices crumbled under the pressure of liquidation of securities which had to be sold at any price.

SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Oct. 30--Leaders of South Korea's armed forces met here last night after curfew began at 10 o'clock to work toward agreement on a new leader to replace President Park Chung Hee.

For some of the competitors, the 1979 Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship, seemed to take a long, long time. It was completed in exactly a year, just in time for the start of the 1980 event.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 The Federal Reserve Board disclosed today that an $800 million error had been discovered in the nation's money supply figures in addition to the $3.7 billion mistake reported last week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) The Air Force asked Congress today for $57 million to build roads and facilities for the first test firing of the MX mobile missile scheduled for early 1983.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 After several hours of spirited, inconclusive debate, President Carter's Pay Advisory Committee today quietly buried the White House's hope that it would make recommendations by the end of the month for a revision of the voluntary standard for pay restraint.

Aspirin's activity is based on chemicals called salicylates, derived from the willow and other plants used as medications since antiquity. More than 2,000 years ago, Hippocrates, the father of Greek medicine, recommended chewing willow bark to counter the pain of childbirth and postpartum fever. In Rome, Pliny the Elder used poplar bark another salicylate source, for sciatic pain.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) The House passed legislation today that would designate 1,400 acres in seven areas for inclusion in the Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore. The bill, passed by a voice vote, also would authorize an additional $39.5 million for land acquisition for the park, which is situated on the southernmost tip of Lake Michigan.

The Brooklyn restaurant where Carmine Galante was shot to death last July 12 white having lunch was closed soon after. Also slain in the shooting were the owner, who was a cousin of Mr. Galante's, and another man. The owner's son, John Turano Jr., also was shot, but he recovered.

Johannes Schiefer, painter of landscapes and portraits and former curator of the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, L.I, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

ALBANY, Oct. 29 Governor Carey presented his proposals today for dealing with this winter's expected home heating problems, stressing Federal aid for the poor, energy conservation and state monitoring of oil prices and price gouging.

WEST BERLIN, Oct. 29 President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, the first French head of state to visit Berlin since Napoleon, affirmed France's security guarantees for the city today as well as a determination "to strive actively for a continuation of detente in Europe."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) The productivity of American business and workers rose at an annual rate of onetenth of 1 percent in the third quarter after two consecutive quarters of sharp declines, the Labor Department reported today.

ROBERT WILSON'S "Edison" is in the midst of a two-week run at the Theatre de Paris, preceded by brief "out-of town" engagements in Lyons and Milan and a series of in-progress, setless performances at the tiny Lion Theater in New York last June.
LONDON, Oct. 29 (AP) British Caledonian Airways, Britain's largest independent airline, said today that it had decided to buy the European-built Airbus to extend its fleet in the mid1980s.

ATLANTA, Oct. 29 (UPI) The police said that a man shot at his home Friday night died today, and that the slaying was the 200th of the year in Atlanta. The victim was identified as Alex Flemister, 56 years old. The police said that Atlanta counted 143 homicides last year.

CALGARY, Alberta, Oct. 29 Dome Petroleum Ltd. announced today that it had encountered "highly significant" shows of crude oil in a second well in the Beaufort Sea about 300 miles east-northeast of Prudhoe Bay.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 (AP) Winds gusting up to 60 miles per hour interrupted power to more than 300,000 southern Californians, capsized boats, toppled trees and fanned a 300-acre fire in the Los Padres National Forest, the authorities said today.

PARIS, Oct. 29 Staggering from the effects of last month's wine Olympiad run by the wine and food magazine The Nouveau Guide Gault-Millau, in which American wines virtually wiped out their French competition, the French wine industry suffered another, if somewhat milder, blow over the weekend. In a less-than-serious wine competition sponsored by London's Evening Standard and Le Figaro here, the Englishmen sweat the field.
Philip Rastelli now in Federal prison in Lewisburg, Pa., has emerged as the new leader of the crime organization that was headed by the late Carmine Galante, police intelligence officials say.
Terry Schroeder scored six goals to lead Pepperdine to a 12-6 victory over Bucknell in the title contest of the national Amateur Athletic Union water polo championships at Fordham University Sunday.

MOST people don't think about setting up a fund for their children's college education until it is too late. The time to start putting away money is when the youngsters enter kindergarten, not when they approach high school graduation.
DCL Inc., a computer leasing company, said that its board had set Jan. 15 as the date for a special meeting of shareholders to consider the proposed complete liquidation of DCL.
SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 29--Policemen and soldiers in armored vehicles opened fire on about 150 anti-Government demonstrators today, and Red Cross officials said that at least 24 persons were killed.
"RACE FOR GOLD," a documentary on public television's "Nova" series, on WNET-TV at 9 o'clock to night, manages to be more disturbing than its producers intended.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) A plan to keep freight trains running for seven more weeks on the western lines of the financially troubled Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad was approved by a Senate committee today.
HONOLULU, Oct. 29 (UPI) Garbage piled up and schools remained shut down throughout Hawaii today as negotiators resumed contract talks to end a weeklong strike by some state workers.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 Only 28 of the nation's 605 Federal judges are women even though more than 45,000 women are now practicing law in the United States, a conference of female judges was told here over the weekend.

"CBS REPORTS" marks its 20th anniversary tonight with "The Baby Makers," a study of artificial mammalian reproduction. The program, which will be seen from 8 to 9 o'clock, maintains the high standards of this admirable series.

The latest poll of New Hampshire's much-surveyed voters discloses the expected that Edward M. Kennedy and Ronald Reagan are almost prohibitive favorites in the Democratic and Republican primaries. But close study of the fine print suggests much more.

If folklore develops out of the way people live, it is noteworthy that parking in New York has apparently not yet produced great stories of our region. It is one of the challenges of urban life that has closely touched the people, a challenge that pits man as an individual against an impenetrable iron curtain that keeps him from space at the curb.

"It brings me to tears that they're not letting the food into Cambodia with all that starvation," said Kazuko Hillyer, one of the producers of a benefit concert last night in Avery Fisher Hall. The benefit was for Indochinese refugees, and Mrs. Hillyer was talking about one of the unexpected frustrations of the task.
They fought a fire, caught a mugger and gave first aid to an epileptic, but the men of Engine Company 41 in the South Bronx said it was all in an hour's work.

A funeral service for Arnold Soboloff, the actor who died Sunday night during the second act of "Peter Pan," in which he was appearing, will be held at 2 P.M. today at the Riverside, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street.

The dugout is the place where Billy Martin is at his best. The only place. In the dugout he knows how to manage a game, how to manage his players, how to manage the umpires, even how to manage himself. Maybe if Billy Martin were a recluse who lived in an apartment attached to the dugout, he would have endured as the Yankees' manager.
Anthony M. Scotto began testifying in his own defense yesterday and asserted that he had "never taken a cent" for himself from any waterfront businessmen.

HENRY, a healthy 55-year-old businessman, was puzzled over losing 20 pounds without dieting during recent months and concerned when he ran a fever up to 101 degrees for two weeks. His doctor diagnosed a viral infection and prescribed aspirin, antibiotics and rest. But the weight loss and fever persisted despite a week's course of treatment. Henry entered a community hospital in Missouri for tests.
Traders in silver futures continued to liquidate their positions yesterday in response to restrictions imposed by the major metals exchange in New York and Chicago last week.

TOKYO, Oct. 29 (UPI) Billows of smoke and jets of steam spilled from Mount Ontake, a 10,100-foot peak situated 120 miles west of Tokyo, yesterday morning. No reports of casualties or damage were received, the police said. It was the first recorded eruption from Ontake, one of the 66 active volcanoes scattered throughout the Japanese archipelago, officials said.

GROTON, Conn., Oct. 29 (AP) Eighteen anti-Trident protesters, including a Roman Catholic priest, were arrested today outside the General Dynamics Corporation's Electric Boat division shipyard where Trident nuclear submarines are built. No injuries were reported.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 29 Ray Perkins sheepishly returned the orange rabbit's foot to his pocket. He did not want to talk about good-luck charms today any more than he wanted to talk about the chances of the Giants' making the National Football League playoffs. Coaches are not supposed to be silly.

The dollar rose sharply against the strong West German mark and gained against all other major currencies in New York and abroad yesterday, enjoying what dealers described as continuing benefits of the Government's latest anti-inflation effort and rising interest rates.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) Representative Ray Roberts, Democrat of Texas, who is serving his 10th term in Congress, announced today that he would not seek re-election next year. Mr. Roberts, 66 years old, began public service in 1935 as director of the National Youth Administration under Lyndon B. Johnson.
WYANDANCH, L.I, Oct. 29 As the teachers strike here entered its seventh week today, the only point of agreement for the two sides seemed to be that no settlement was in sight.
For almost two decades, Terry Rudd had been watching the United States Equestrian Team compete in horse shows and wondering if she ever would be chosen for the squad.

OTTAWA, Oct. 29 The Canadian Government abandoned its plan today to move its embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem after receiving a report from a special Ambassador to the Middle East saying the step could have an adverse effect on the peace process in the region.
On the 50th anniversary of "Black Tuesday," the darkest day of the 1929 market crash, stock prices dawdled along a narrow path yesterday to finish with token gains.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 29 In a rare display of concern about an individual, the President of the General Assembly today asked Poland's representative to the United Nations to discuss the case of a missing employee, Alicja Wesolowska.

The New York Legislature enacted a "truth in testing" law last June and we applauded the idea. Even then, however, it was clear that the testing industry could not meet the law's demands by Jan. 1, when it is scheduled to take effect. And now there is such panic and confusion over the law among testing companies, state officials and students that unless its effective date is delayed, it will do more harm than good.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 29 (Reuters) Twelve people died and 39 were injured today when their truck crashed into the closed gate of a railroad crossing near Ahmadabad in western India, the Press Trust of India reported.
THE cost of feeding a family of four in New York City fell last week to the lowest level in nearly six months, the city's Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday.
The fat dog is no joke. Obesity, veterinarians say, is a major canine health problem. By one estimate, 28 percent of the domestic dog population a decade ago was overweight.

The microsurgery team and ambulance corpsmen who saved a police officer's severed leg and a Bronx woman who apprehended a confidence man were among those honored yesterday by the Police Department for public service.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 A bill that would lock up 95 million acres of Alaskan lands in national parks and forests and in wilderness areas but would allow petroleum prospecting in the caribou calving areas of the Arctic Wildlife Range was reported out today by the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee.

Gen. William M. Hoge, who built the 1,500-mile Alaska Highway in 1942, commanded the combat unit that captured the Remagen bridge over the Rhine River in 1945 and later served as commander of all United States Army troops in postwar Europe, died yesterday at Munson Army Hospital at Fort Leavenworth, Kan. He was 85 years old.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 The Senate moved today to give Congress a measure of control over Presidential authority to limit imports of foreign oil and impose fees on such imports. The vote was 70 to 23.

DENVER, Oct. 30 (AP) Centers Dan Issel of Denver and Bill Cartwright of New York connected with their season-highs of 32 points tonight, but Issel got more support from his teammates as the Nuggets scored their second straight National Basketball Association victory by defeating the Knicks, 121-112.

This time last year, prospects for reforming the nation's cumbersome welfare programs looked bleak. Congress had summarily rejected the Carter Administration's original reform plan as too ambitious and expensive.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 30 The diplomats here are usually punctilious about the rules of etiquette. But today a few took off the gloves and scrapped with the political equivalent of bare knuckles as Cuba once again fell short in a bid for a seat on the Security Council.

A group in Phoenix is fighting for Frank Lloyd Wright and against a new highway. But this is a preservation battle with a twist. The house being battled over, a fine example of Wright's prairie style and built in 1939, is no longer there.

The financial arrangments committing New York State to pay most of the cost of the proposed American Stock Exchange building while Amex would pay only a low subsdidized rent was criticized yesterday at a legislative hearing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 John B. Connally has bought the earliest Presidential campaign commercial ever, for broadcast tonight, using television to steal a march on his competitors and try to set himself up as the Republican Party's only realistic alternative to Ronald Reagan.

OTTAWA, Oct. 30 The new Prime Minister of Canada is Joe Clark of High River, Alberta a place about the size of Plains, Ga. and he will be meeting here in the next few days with President Carter.

The National Horse Show, which started in the cobblestone and gaslight era, got under way yesterday at Madison Square Garden, and the United States Equestrian Team promptly took a commanding lead.

But its recommendations, as the commission itself acknowledges, may not suffice to assure nuclear safety.

VIENNA, Oct. 30 (UPI) The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries does not plan an extraordinary session to discuss oil prices before its regular meeting next month, an OPEC official said today.

Rachele Guidi Mussolini, the widow of Benito Mussolini, died yesterday at her home near Forli, Italy, where she had run a small restaurant-hotel for the last 15 years. She was 89 years old, having outlived Italy's Fascist dictator by a third of a century.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 "As protection against financial illusion or insanity," John Kenneth Galbraith observed in "The Great Crash," "memory is far better than law."

TOKYO, Oct. 30 Japan's new Parliament, hobbled by a power struggle in the governing Liberal Democratic Party, elected a speaker and deputy speaker of the House of Representatives today but adjourned the opening session until tomorrow without receiving a nomination for prime minister from the Liberal Democrats.
TAD MOSEL'S "All the Way Home" appeared in 1960, won the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 1961 and, except for an Off Off Broadway revival a few seasons ago, has not been seen here since.
Top education officials were summoned to City Hall yesterday by Mayor Koch, who heard them outline a plan for tentative cutbacks to cover an unexpected $45 million budget deficit.
IT was hard not to think of Riccardo Muti's program with the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night as something of a calling card.

BRUSSELS, Wednesday, Oct. 31 (UPI) Angola's Ambassador to Belgium said today that airborne South African troops had invaded Angola, striking near a major Cuban air base on the country's west coast.
The Xerox Corporation yesterday introduced three medium- and high-volume copying and duplicating machines that computer industry analysts say fill a clear performance gap in Xerox's product line.
An exhibition of paintings by the leading abstract expressionist Clyfford Still will be shown at the Metropolitan Museum of Art from Nov. 17 through Feb. 3, 1980.

Joseph Cooper, the salesman at the center of Billy Martin's dismissal, said yesterday that the former New York Yankee manager had threatened him and then had hit him with a "sucker punch."

DETROIT, Oct. 30 The Chrysler Corporation today reported a loss of $460.6 million for the third quarter, the largest quarterly loss from continuing operations ever incurred in the history of American enterprise.

In pro football these days the teams seldom field the same 11 players on two consecutive plays. The comings and goings from the sidelines to the offensive or defensive huddles signal the age of specialization, which has never has been more prevalent in the National Football League.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) The biggest monthly bill for oil imports that the United States has ever had contributed to a $2.83 billion deficit in the nation's trade accounts last month, the largest deficit in eight months, the Commerce Department said today.

LONDON, Oct. 30 (Reuters) Sir Barnes Wallis, the ingenious designer of airships and jet planes who also invented the World War II "dambuster" bouncing bombs, died in the hospital today at the age of 92.

Paul Dietzel, the athletic director of Louisiana State University, said yesterday that he had refused to switch the scheduled kickoff of the Tigers' home game against Alabama, preventing ABC from showing it on national television Nov. 10.

Gold prices rose by $3.50 to $5.50 an ounce in major bullion trading centers yesterday. The dollar was mixed in relation to other major foreign currencies, showing only mild reaction to the report of a large United States trade deficit last month.
WARSAW, Oct. 30 Basking in the worldwide attention showered on its famous native son, Pope John Paul II, the Roman Catholic Church in Poland is flourishing as never before.

From a sampling of 32 fresh apple ciders purchased from supermarkets, greenmarkets and roadside stands in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania,the taste panel selected these five as outstanding. The cider producers are listed according to the number of votes received in the final testing. The last three received an equal number of votes, and are listed alphabetically.

BOSTON, Oct. 30 Arguments are to begin here tomorrow in Federal District Court on a lawsuit to stop again the sale of oil and gas exploration leases on the fertile Georges Bank fishing grounds off Cape Cod. The sale is currently scheduled for next Tuesday.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 30 The latest wave of political violence to convulse El Salvador appears to reflect a decision by extreme leftist groups to undermine the authority of the country's new Government before it can gain popular support.
The United States Steel Corporation yesterday reported a third-quarter profit drop of 8.4 percent from the results for the comparable 1978 period.

The debate in the Congress over the strategic arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union may be having repercussions for the corporate world. Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., the retired Chief of Naval Operations, has resigned as president and chief executive officer of American Medical Buildings Inc., to take, in his words, "a more active part" in the debate on the treaty.

The Consolidated Rail Corporation, the Government-sponsored freight railroad created from bankrupt Eastern carriers, reported yesterday a loss of $40 million in the third quarter, $8.5 million less than the loss recorded in last year's third quarter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 The staff of the Federal Communications Commission reported today that television broadcasters had fallen short of commission goals for children's progamming, but the commissioners hesitated to order the industry to increase the programs immediately.

HARTFORD, Oct. 30 Republicans in the State Senate introduced a supplemental energy package today that would include a $300 property tax deferral for homeowners to use for winterizing their houses, state tax exemptions for all alternative energy systems and an increase in the low-interest winterization loan program to $15 million.
Thirteen shoe-repair shops gave estimates ranging from $7 to $30 recently for fixing the same pair of dilapidated leather shoes.

TULSA, Okla., Oct. 30 (Reuters) The Cities Service Company said today that it had signed a contract with Tunisia for oil exploration on a 180,877-acre tract off Kerkennah Island, Tunisia, in the Gulf of Gabes. It said the initial contract provided for a geophysical survey and the drilling of one test well.

Several more banks raised their prime lending rates to 15 percent yesterday, but most major ones held back on matching the increase initiated last Friday by Citibank, which is second in size behind the Bank of America.

Past and present operatic luminaries and the family and friends of Eleanor Robson Belmont attended a memorial service yesterday for the woman credited with creating much of the support that has enabled the Metropolitan Opera Company to endure.

For the first time, two major department stores, Bloomingdale's and Abraham Straus, will be tenants of the same shopping center, Federated Department Stores Inc., parent company of both retailers, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) Both the Senate and the House of Representative today approved a freeze on plans to shut down the western lines of the financially ailing Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 30 (Reuters) The Brazilian trade deficit widened to $1.59 billion in the first nine months of this year from $678 million in the comparable period last year, the Finance Ministry said today. The value of exports in the first nine months was $10.98 billion, up from $9.11 billion in the comparable period last year, while imports amounted to $12.57 billion, against $9.79 billion in the year-ago period, it said.

DENNY GOODMAN was swinging again last night at a private party at the Rainbow Grill with a tight, rhythmi cally supple quartet and several special guests, including Helen Ward, his original band vocalist.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 The Carter Administration announced today that it was imposing a quota on additional categories of Chinese textile and apparel products sold in this country as part of efforts to win Congressional approval of the China trade agreement that was sent to Capitol Hill last week.

CHICAGO (UPI) Trans World Airlines said today that it planned to file a request with the Civil Aeronautics Board for permission to offer a greater discount on "super coach" fares on certain flights between Chicago and Los Angeles. The airline said that it would seek a one-way fare of $119. The airline's current regular coach fare is $229 and the "super coach" fare is $182.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 The President's Commission on the Accident at Three Mile Island has found that, despite prevailing confusion and contradictory statements from sources supplying information, the news media generally attempted to give a balanced presentation of the accident at the nuclear power facility last March.
LONDON, Oct. 30 (AP) Chrysler U.K., the French-owned car maker, reported today that it lost $36.6 million in the first half of this year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) A Government index designed to forecast economic trends showed surprising strength in September, rising by the largest amount since April 1978, the Commerce Department reported today.

PARIS, Nov. 9 (Reuters) Paris airtraffic controllers refused to give takeoff clearances for four and a half hours today and said there would be more stoppages over the weekend and next week. Major airlines have rescheduled flights to bypass France so the controllers' action mainly affected internal flights.

Fredrica Teer, a consultant to business and private organizations and executive director for the National Black Theater, died Tuesday at the home of her sister in Manhattan. She was 43 years old and lived in New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) Farmers are harvesting a record corn crop of 7.59 billion bushels this fall, the Agriculture Department said today. Robin Cousins of Britain, a 22year-old figure skater, appears primed to win a gold medal at the 1980 Winter Olympics in Lake Placid, N.Y. He placed third in the world championships in 1978, was second this year, and won the gold medal in the free-skating competition both years. An extraordinary free skater, with a dazzling spirit to match, Cousins has grace, charm and an identifiable style that one former figureskating judge calls "exciting."

A prosecutor told the jury in the trial of Anthony M. Scotto yesterday that the best evidence in the case was "Mr. Scotto's own voice" on tape recordings of conversations about cash payments from a waterfront businessman.

A Brooklyn man was arrested last night and charged with helping Joanne Chesimard, a former leader of the Black Liberation Army, escape last week from a New Jersey prison where she was serving a life term for the slaying of a state trooper, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

People in New York City expressed anger and frustration about the American hostages being held in Iran as they gathered yesterday in lobbies and on plazas and sidewalks to chat during breaks from work.

A former New York City correction officer testified yesterday that he received more than $5,000 from a freelance writer for providing prison pictures and information about David R. Berkowitz after Mr. Berkowitz's 1977 arrest as the "Son of Sam" killer.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 9 In the mid1960's, the people who had been in charge around here for a century could see the change coming. Upper-class whites, Republican and conservative, felt their city was being overrun by blacks who one day would outvote them and take control of government in Oakland.

The Barclays American Corporation has agreed to purchase 138 consumer finance offices of two companies being acquired by the Beneficial Corporation. The cost to Barclays American is expected to be approximately $200 million.

QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 9 (UPI) Andres Gomez of Ecuador, a virtual unknown on the international circuit, upset Vitas Gerulaitis of the United States, 6-4, 7-6, and reached the quarterfinals of a $50,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament today. Gerulaitis, the world's fifth-ranked player, recently won the Australian indoor title.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 The Carter Administration, refining its military budget proposals for the next fiscal year, plans a large increase in naval shipbuilding and an expansion of air and sea transport to deploy strike forces rapidly in emergencies, according to well-placed officials.

HOUSTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) Exxon U.S.A. said today that its stocks of crude oil were 19 percent lower at the end of last month than they were a year earlier. However, the company said that its supply of home heating oil and other distillates at that time was 6 percent higher than last year.

ROME, Nov. 9 In apparently the first disclosure of its kind, the Roman Catholic Church announced today that its central administration, the Roman Curia, was operating with a budget deficit expected to reach $20.24 million by Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 State Department officials said today that the Iranian Government had assured the American Embassy in Teheran three times that, despite the Shah's presence in the United States for medical reasons, the embassy would receive adequate security.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 Nikola Kavaja, a Serb terrorist already sewing a 20-year sentence for bombing conspiracy, was convicted today by a Federal District Court jury of hijacking an American Airlines jetliner on a flight last June 20 from New York to Chicago. He could be sentenced to life in prison.

ATHENS, Nov. 9 (UPI) John Mahaffey and Hale Irwin needed five and a half hours to complete 18 holes today in moving the United States to an eight-stroke lead after the second round of the 27th World Cup golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 Once the Iranian crisis is over, members of Congress are saying, the Administration will have to answer some tough questions about the events leading up to the seizure of the United States Embassy in Teheran. Lawmakers also say that they will be demanding some form of retaliation against Iran, either diplomatic or military.

As a result of allegations of misconduct uncovered in a monthlong state inquiry, the director of the Bronx Children's Psychiatric Center began a paid leave of absence yesterday pending completion of the investigation.

LISBON, Nov. 14 (Reuters) Ambassador Ephraim Eldar of Israel, wounded in a machine-gun and grenade attack outside his embassy here yesterday, is out of danger after an operation, hospital officials said today.

GREENVILLE, Miss., Nov. 14 (AP) A 16-year-old Greenville youth was ordered held without bond today on charges that he murdered the Rev. Eugene Chatagnier, a Roman Catholic priest who was found earlier in the week shot three times.
New York City's Sanitation Department is marshaling its flotilla of plows, salt spreaders and manpower to minimize the impact of the winter's first snowfall.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Nov. 12 A letter mailed to members of Jewish organizations here the weekend before Election Day by a prominent town Democrat attempted to discourage voting for candidates of the anti-abortion Right to Life Party and the Conservative Party on ethnic and religious grounds and by a reference to the Holocaust.

California sold $150 million of tripleA bonds yesterday that were priced to yield as much as 7 percent, the highest rate of return on top-quality state bonds available to investors since 1970. Even with their rare yields, however, the bonds did not sell rapidly. About $90 million of them remained unsold at the end of the day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark, sent last week by President Carter to seek the release of American hostages in Teheran, was recalled to Washington tonight without ever having reached Iran.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 The House of Representatives tonight approved legislation to provide $5.9 billion in loans, loan guarantees and other fiscal assistance for companies in economically distressed areas.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Nov. 14 (UPI) Coast Guard officers investigating an apparently abandoned 25-foot boat in the Intracoastal Waterway peeled back a tarpaulin on the deck today and found 10 Haitians who were trying to enter the country illegally. The eight men and two women were turned over to Border Patrol officials.

The Union Carbide Corporation announced that it would build a multimillion-dollar air-separation plant in Brownsville, Tex. The facility will produce 1,500 tons of oxygen daily, 1,320 tons of nitrogen and 68 tons of argon. The construction is scheduled to be completed in the third quarter of 1981.
Research on the chemistry of life and the functioning of the human brain was honored yesterday when the 1979 Albert Lasker Medical Research Awards were won by two Americans and a British scientist.

HARTFORD, Nov. 14 The Motors Insurance Corporation will eliminate such factors as age, sex and marital status in determining auto insurance rates for Connecticut drivers, John J. MacDonald, president, said today.

A request by Roosevelt Raceway for one continuous seven-month meeting in 1980, which would conflict with the harness-racing season at New Jersey's Meadowlands, was presented yesterday to the State Racing and Wagering Board. Yonkers Raceway, on the other hand, asked four short meetings, alternating with Roosevelt. The board deferred a decision.

TORONTO, Nov. 14 Until this year, Val de Loire, an import by way of France and Spain, had been Melanie Smith's No. 1 open jumper. But the aged chestnut gelding has had to take a back seat to Miss Smith's newest mount, Calypso, for the last three months.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP) The head of President Carter's campaign in Illinois says that a $5,000 contribution by Mayor Jane M. Byrne of Chicago to the campaign of Senator Edward M. Kennedy might be illegal.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14 (Reuters) A Turkish Cypriot spokesman said today that his community would boycott this year's General Assembly debate on Cyprus, as it did in 1976 and 1977, and it would not regard as binding any resolution adopted by the world body. The debate is scheduled to begin tomorrow.
The Gulf Oil Corporation confirmed yesterday that it would cut back its shipments of crude oil to Japan because future supplies were uncertain.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Nov. 14 (UPI) Pat Nixon was reported in "improved" condition today at San Clemente General Hospital where she is being treated for bronchial pneumonia. Her husband, Richard M. Nixon, spent an hour with the former First Lady last night and 40 minutes this morning.
LONDON, Nov. 14 The Government today proposed a tightening of the rules on immigration that would significantly reduce the number of nonwhite people moving to Britain.

WHO, these days, cares about detail? For one thing, who can afford it? For another, who has the time? Ours is a hurried world, with convenience the sum mum bonum, "easy care" the guiding principle. The dignity of craftsmanship has bowed to the imperative of efficiency.

Service on the Green Bus Line will resume Sunday morning after a 17-week strike, a company representative said yesterday. The line's 200 buses serve south Queens. Drivers and mechanics for the line, which carries approximately 100,000 Queens riders daily, walked off the job July 1 over the issues of salary and cost-of-living adjustments. The union ratified a new contract on Nov. 9.

NISHINOMIYA, Japan, Nov. 14 (AP) A team of American major league all-stars rallied on home runs by Ted Simmons and Larry Bowa and edged the Japan All-Stars, 6-5, today in the opener of a two-game series between the teams.

IF planted within the next few days, paper-white narcissus will be in full bud by Dec. 23 and in perfect condition for gift giving. In the recipient's home, they will burst into cheerful and fragrant bloom. A single poinsettia surrounded by pots of paper-white narcissus makes a festive display.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 14 The three virtual strangers responsible for the Jets' place-kicking the snapper, the holder, the kicker assembled today in an attempt to avoid another fiasco when they face the Bears in Chicago on Sunday.

The New Apollo, where "Bent" starts previews next Monday night, is the first of three theaters on 42d Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue to be converted from movie houses into legitimate theaters, with the entrances shifted to 43d Street.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (UPI) A United States immigration judge today ordered one of three Iranians arrested at O'Hare International Airport to be deported from the United States.

A detailed study of conditions on Long Island has resulted in a conclusion that ordinary energy conservation measures and the use of solar energy could reduce dependence on imported oil and stimulate the American economy far more than constructing nuclear power plants.

The Vienna Philharmonic played Beethoven's Ninth Symphony last night at Carnegie Hall under the direction of Leonard Bernstein. This concert was reviewed py Harold C. Schonberg when it was performed at Kennedy Center on Oct. 29. Mr. Schonberg said, "This performance simply pulsated with life."

PETER ORTH, who gave a debut recital in Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night as a result of winning the Naumburg International Piano Competition in memory of William Kapell, proved to be a refreshing and distinctive musical personality.

"THE French Atlantic Affair," beginning a three-part run on ABC-TV tonight at 9 o'clock, is one of those gigan tic constructions held together with the glue of familiar faces and a plot so incredible as to be perversely fascinating.

An applicant for a license to operate a new television station in Atlantic City urged the Federal Communications Commission yesterday to dismiss a rival application by a group with casino interests.

DEARBORN, Mich., Nov. 14 Philip Caldwell, president and chief executive officer of the Ford Motor Company, has spelled out some unpleasant news to salaried employees in the November issues of Ford World, the salaried employees' newsletter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 Japan could face restrictions on car sales in the United States if it does not follow the European example and invest in a major automotive manufacturing operation here, Reubin O. Askew, the special trade representative, warned in an interview.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) The House voted today to reverse present law and allow more foreign meat into the country when American supplies are tight and retail prices are rising.

BERN, Nov. 14 (Reuters) Switzerland said today that the interest rate on Federal medium-term bonds would be increased. DETROIT, Nov. 14 The nation's Big Three auto makers reported today that their sales of new American-made cars plunged 26.7 percent in the first 10 days of November, with the Chrysler Corporation showing the steepest drop, of 43.4 percent. Sales at each of the three were more than 20 percent below year-earlier levels.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) Gen. William C. Westmoreland, retired, former Army Chief of Staff, warned Congress today that morale would suffer if women were allowed to fight alongside men in war. He said the issue was too important to be based on a simple social trend.

The State Board of Regents, charging that a "serious lack of medical care" has "contributed significantly" to learning disabilities, said yesterday that most physical examinations and immunizations of pupils should be conducted in the schools the children attend. The board recommended that the medical program be paid for by Medicaid or fees charged to parents.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 When one nation deliberately infringes on the sovereignty of another, and seizes prisoners in the bargain, that is by definition an act of war.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 With George Meany presiding for the last time, the executive council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations today endorsed President Carter's call for restraint on Iran, called for a labor campaign to help Cambodians, admitted a new affiliate union and proposed a per capita dues increase of 3 cents a month.
SHEFFIELD, ENGLAND COMING up the sweeping driveway to Broom Hall, the great 18th-century Georgian house, a visitor assumes that he has gotten lost, or is in the wrong place.

LONDON, Nov. 14 Another deadline in the 10-week-old talks on the political future of Zimbabwe Rhodesia slipped by without a decision today, but there were signs of significant behind-the-scenes progress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 The United States froze all official Iranian assets in American banks today, only hours after Iran announced that it planned to withdraw billions of dollars in funds from this country and transfer them to other ones.
DALLAS, Nov. 14 (Reuters) Both Texas Senators have called for an immediate end to training of Iranian Air Force pilots in the United States.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 14 (UPI) A powerful earthquake ripped through 14 mud-brick villages in northeastern Iran today and killed at least 248 persons, most of them in their sleep, relief officials reported.

QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 14 (UPI) A volcano on Isabela Island in the Galapagos archipelago began spouting lava and volcanic ash yesterday, forcing the evacuation of residents of the area to Puerto Villamil, the island's main town. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. The Galapagos, in the Pacific Ocean, belong to Ecuador.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 Service station owners and some officials are disgruntled because Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. yesterday signed an order making mandatory the "odd-even day" restriction on gasoline sales that had been discarded by most of those California counties that took it up last spring on a voluntary basis.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 14 (UPI) Two trains collided today in Matunga, a suburb of Bombay, killing five people and injuring 50, officials said.
Duncan M. Spencer, honorary chairman of the Fiduciary Trust Company of New York, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan at the age of 82.
SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 13 The United States has quietly welcomed South Korea into the exclusive group of industrial nations with which it consults annually on major economic policy developments.
OSLO-Should Congress try to make big United States banks more responsive to the people's will by appointing the chairman and directors itself, instead of letting shareholders elect them?

IF New Country Gear has its way, there will be a new American Revolution afoot. Bettye Martin, president; Raymond Waiter, creative vice president and designer, and Judy Garb, mar keting vice president, have put together an enviable if carefully studied collection of household items based on a countrified theme.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 Senator Edward M. Kennedy has paid a price for accelerating his campaign timetable to gain control over the sprawling Draft Kennedy movement and catch up with President Carter's head start in organization, some Kennedy partisans concede, and that price is a somewhat ragged entry into his formal campaign.

As ridership on commuter lines continue to rise, a trend attributed partly to fears of yet another gasoline shortage, service problems appear to have increased, too. Following figures show ridership increases and on-time performances of rail lines in New York and New Jersey, as well as traffic on bridge and tunnel crossings in the metropolitan area.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 14 (AP) Indonesia is raising its price for some types of exported oil by about 11 percent to $23.50 a barrel, the Government said today. Indonesia is the seventh member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise prices in recent weeks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) Edward Anderson, a farmer from Waterloo, Neb., was elected today as master of the National Grange at the organization's annual meeting in Lancaster, Pa., according to the national office here.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14 The General Assembly demanded overwhelmingly today that Vietnam withdraw its troops from Cambodia.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 14 Ann Meyers has agreed to sign a three-year contract worth $130,000 with the New Jersey Gems of the Women's Basketball League, the team announced today.
The stock market made a moderate gain in continued light trading yesterday after an initial selloff that followed news of the freeze on Iranian assets in the United States.

PEKING, Nov. 14 A transcript of the trial of Wei Jingsheng, the dissident, quotes him as having said that, if a citizen cannot criticize the leaders, China today is little different from what it was in the Cultural Revolution when the Gang of Four, the now discredited radicals, ruled the country.

The area director for the United States Customs Service in New Jersey has been suspended following a month-long investigation into allegations of kickbacks and illegal payoffs to allow cargo to enter the United States duty free, a spokesman for the Customs Service said yesterday.

The RCA Corporation, after a twoyear search, yesterday named Maurice R. Valente, a well-regarded executive vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, to be president and chief operating officer.
William F. Arbogast, a former correspondent for The Associated Press, died Tuesday. He was 71 years old and a resident of Alexandria, Va.

President Carter assured space agency officials yesterday of his full support for the manned space shuttle and his intention to ask Congress for additional funds to help prevent further delays in the troubled multibillion-dollar project.
LANDOVER, Md., Nov. 14 (UPI) The Washington Capitals released their coach, Danny Belisle, today and replaced him with Gary Green, coach of the National Hockey League club's Hershey affiliate.
SAGINAW, Mich., Nov. 14 (AP) About 1,850 workers struck a Chevrolet brake plant of the General Motors Corporation over local issues today.

The front-office staff of the New York Mets has been told what the public already surmised: that the club "probably would be sold," but that there was no rush to sell and the sifting of offers would take time.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 14 In announcing that it intended to withdraw its funds from American banks and their overseas branches, Iran declared today that the move was justified on the ground that banking interests were responsible for the admission of the deposed Shah to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) A Federal appeals court today upheld the conviction of Representative Charles C. Diggs Jr. on charges that he took kickbacks from staff members and had Government paychecks issued to persons who handled his personal affairs.

A revised urban renewal plan to redevelop 42d Street at Times Square recommends demolishing the wedge-shaped skyscraper known as One Times Square. The building was formerly the Times Tower and then the Allied Chemical Building.

WALTER BERRY is a veteran member of the Vienna State Opera and hence has been in this country during the company's visit to Washington and, more vestigially, New York. Tuesday night Mr. Berry took time off for a lieder recital at the 92d Street Y, a recital that was full of sturdy competence and good intentions and wound up sounding rather perfunctory.

LONDON, Nov. 14 The Conservative Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher yielded last night to protests at home and abroad against its plan to cut more than $5 million from spending on the British Broadcasting Corporation's foreign-language services.

AT the time of the divorce, a Michigan court decided that custody of 10-year-old Allison and 6-year-old Seth (not their real names) would go to their father. A year later, after a routine visit with their mother, Allison and Seth were not returned.

UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 14 (Reuters) Prime Minister John Lynch of Ireland, in the United States for discussions with Administration officials, met Secretary General Kurt Waldheim today for talks on Lebanon. He was accompanied by the Irish Foreign Minister, Michael O'Kennedy, and Ireland's representative at the United Nations, Paul Keating.

PARIS, Nov. 14 (AP) The French Government today appointed Renaud de la Geniere as the new governor of the Bank of France for a five-year period. He has been deputy governor of the bank since 1974 and will replace Bernard Clappier, who is retiring.

BEDFORD, N.H., Nov. 14 (AP) The director of the Federal Office of Management and Budget defended President Carter's economic policies today, warning against the "glib phrases and easy solutions" of other politicians.
Harold S. Geneen, the $1.1-milliona-year board chairman of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, said yesterday that he would relinquish his post at the end of the year.
